questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of moderate postprandial discomfort. The patient previously experienced similar symptoms and at that time was diagnosed with a type II paraesophageal hernia. He states that he has not kept up with the lifestyle and dietary modifications that initially helped relieve the symptoms. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia that are well-controlled with lisinopril and atorvastatin. Lifestyle and dietary modifications are recommended again, and a low-dose H2-receptor antagonist is prescribed as needed. Four weeks later, the patient has not had relief from the reflux symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe an H2-receptor antagonist twice daily and reassess in two weeks
Continue low-dose H2 receptor agonist as needed for four more weeks and reassess

questions.solution:
This 65-year-old man presents to the clinic for symptoms consistent with acid reflux in the setting of a known type II paraesophageal/hiatal hernia. He is advised to re-start lifestyle and dietary modifications and prescribed an H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA) as needed for symptomatic management. However, after following this plan for four weeks, he continues to have refractory reflux. The most appropriate next step in management is to increase the frequency of the H2RA to daily and to reassess the patient in two weeks.        

 Management of hiatal hernias is like the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Initially, patients are educated and counseled on the importance of dietary and lifestyle modifications. These include interventions such as weight loss, elevation of the head at night, and elimination of acid reflux triggers (e.g., alcohol, fatty foods, etc.). If reflux symptoms persist, an H2RA can be used as needed. If after four weeks, symptoms persist, then the H2RA should be changed to daily, and the patient should be reassessed for treatment response after two weeks. If there is no adequate response, then a low-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) should be prescribed and titrated upward based on symptoms.       

Patients who have refractory reflux symptoms despite appropriate medical management, can be referred for surgical management. Surgical management involves laparoscopic hernia reduction and repair, along with fundoplication to re-establish the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and prevent recurrence of GERD.    

Option Analysis

❌ Refer for elective surgical management  :
Incorrect: Surgical management (with hiatal herniorrhaphy with or without fundoplication) should be considered when patients have symptoms that are refractory to medical management. This patient should first have the dosing of the H2RA changed from as needed to daily. 
❌ Prescribe low-dose proton pump inhibitor daily  :
Incorrect: Low-dose proton pump inhibitor should be considered only after a daily H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA) has been tried for two weeks without improvement of symptoms. This patient has been taking a low-dose of H2RA on an as-needed basis and should be switched to a daily H2RA before considering a proton pump inhibitor.  
✅ Prescribe an H2-receptor antagonist twice daily and reassess in two weeks :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continue low-dose H2 receptor agonist as needed for four more weeks and reassess :
Incorrect: If patients fail to respond to H2RA as needed, for four weeks, they should be switched to daily H2 receptor agonists.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal and chest pain for three hours and two episodes of vomiting, the most recent one with hematemesis. The parents report that he is not able to swallow solids or liquids. Parents report that the child was playing in the playroom unsupervised when these symptoms began. There is no history of similar episodes and no history of diarrhea or fever. He has no surgical history, and family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 98/59 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the child appears irritable, and there is mild abdominal tenderness with a soft and nondistended abdomen. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia .  Licensed under; CC BY 3.0

choices.text: Intubate and place on mechanical ventilation
Obtain intraosseous access for rapid fluid resuscitation

questions.solution:
The child presents with chest and abdominal pain, vomiting, and an episode of hematemesis following unsupervised play. Chest x-ray confirms the presence of a button battery in the esophagus, making esophagitis secondary to button battery ingestion the predicted cause of hematemesis and upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Emergent endoscopy is required for removal of the button battery.       

Ingestion of foreign bodies is common in children. Foreign bodies that can cause significant trauma to the GI tract include sharp objects and button batteries. Most button battery ingestions occur in children younger than 6 years and can result in esophageal mucosal damage, necrosis, and perforation, which can lead to upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Patients with button battery ingestion often present with acute GI symptoms such as vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, and they can drool and have irritability. Other symptoms include hematemesis, hemoptysis, melena, and abdominal pain. Physical exams may reveal epigastric tenderness.        

Chest x-ray should be performed to help make the diagnosis and localize the foreign body. If a button battery is identified and found to be in the esophagus, immediate endoscopic removal is necessary and should not be delayed to avoid complications such as perforation and necrosis. During endoscopy, the mucosa should be inspected for the extent, depth, and location of the injury.        

Option Analysis

❌ Intubate and place on mechanical ventilation :
Incorrect: Intubation and mechanical ventilation should be initiated in patients with foreign body aspiration and signs of respiratory distress, which are not noted in this patient. Rather, this patient has ingested a button battery, and an urgent endoscopy should be performed. 
❌ Perform gastric lavage :
Incorrect: Gastric lavage might be useful or better visualization of the upper gastrointestinal tract when an endoscopy is performed. This patient’s abdominal pain and hematemesis are secondary to button battery ingestion, and urgent endoscopy should be performed.  
✅ Perform urgent gastrointestinal endoscopy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain intraosseous access for rapid fluid resuscitation :
Incorrect: Intraosseous access is a helpful technique for providing rapid infusion of fluids for patients with signs of hemodynamic instability, particularly in the pediatric population. However, this patient is stable, and his abdominal pain and hematemesis are secondary to button battery ingestion; therefore, urgent endoscopy is required.  
❌ Transfuse packed red blood cells  :
Incorrect: Packed red blood cell transfusion may be needed in this patient with upper gastrointestinal bleeding if he had signs of hemorrhagic shock such as tachycardia and hypotension. These findings are absent in this patient, and he should have emergent endoscopy performed.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after multiple episodes of large hematemesis over the past 30 minutes. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and cirrhosis. He was found confused and drowsy at home, and his family called emergency medical services. In the emergency department, he appears lethargic and moans in response to painful stimuli. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, heart rate is 125 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor, diaphoresis, spider angiomas, abdominal distention with a fluid wave, and melena on the rectal exam. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with massive hematemesis, hypotension, tachycardia, hypoxemia, and altered mental status in the context of known cirrhosis, suggestive of an upper gastrointestinal bleed likely from esophageal variceal bleeding. The patient’s altered mental status and active bleeding indicate an imminent risk for airway compromise from aspiration. The most immediate priority is securing the airway via endotracheal intubation to prevent respiratory failure.

Acute management of patients presenting with vomiting begins with assessing and stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC). In unstable patients such as those with massive hematemesis, IV access should be established, fluid resuscitation should be provided, and vital signs should be continuously monitored. If there is a risk of aspiration, such as in patients with altered mental status or ongoing hematemesis, endotracheal intubation should be performed. Once the patient is stabilized, a focused history and physical examination should be performed to identify potential causes, followed by appropriate diagnostic testing (e.g., labs, imaging).   

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide is prescribed as pharmacologic therapy for variceal bleeding; however, it would not be the first step in management. Airway protection must be addressed first.  
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergency endoscopy:
Incorrect: Endoscopy is the definitive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for variceal bleeding, but it cannot be performed safely in an unstable patient who is at risk for aspiration. Intubation must precede endoscopy in a patient like this one with altered mental status and active bleeding.
❌ Oxygen via nasal cannula:
Incorrect: Oxygen can improve hypoxemia temporarily; however, it is insufficient for airway protection in a patient with active hematemesis and altered mental status.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Imaging of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated. This clinical presentation strongly suggests variceal bleeding. Imaging would delay life-saving interventions.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe retrosternal chest pain and difficulty swallowing. The pain began abruptly two hours ago after he swallowed a tough piece of steak. He describes the pain as severe, sharp, retrosternal, and worse with swallowing. He has no fever, chills, or shortness of breath. He has a history of diabetes, for which he takes metformin, and hypertension, for which he takes atenolol. He has a history of Zenker diverticulum. He underwent thoracic surgery for a lung nodule five years ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a distended neck with crepitus over the chest with palpation. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the biggest risk factor for this patient’s underlying condition?
 

Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe retrosternal chest pain and difficulty swallowing after swallowing a tough piece of steak. On physical exam, he has crepitus, and the chest X-ray shows pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema suggestive of an esophageal perforation. In this patient, the presence of a Zenker diverticulum likely significantly increased his risk of esophageal perforation. A Zenker diverticulum refers to an outpouching at the junction of the hypopharynx and esophagus that can trap food and bacteria and lead to inflammation, making the esophagus more vulnerable to perforation.

Esophageal perforation can result from iatrogenic, traumatic (i.e. fish bone), or spontaneous causes. Patients with esophageal perforation typically present with sudden, severe chest pain localized behind the sternum, between the shoulder blades, or in the abdomen. The pain typically is exacerbated by swallowing and is associated with dysphagia and odynophagia. Physical examination may reveal crepitus, which is a sign of subcutaneous emphysema, and Hamman's sign, which is characterized by a crunching or popping sound synchronized with the heartbeat. As the condition progresses, mediastinitis, sepsis, and shock may develop.

Option Analysis

✅ Zenker diverticulum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of diabetes:
Incorrect: Having diabetes does not increase the risk of esophageal perforation.  
❌ History of hypertension:
Incorrect: Having hypertension does not increase the risk of esophageal perforation.  
❌ Metformin use:
Incorrect: Metformin use does not increase the risk of esophageal perforation.  
❌ Thoracic surgery:
Incorrect: Prior thoracic surgery may cause adhesions or changes in anatomy but will not directly increase the risk of esophageal perforation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department two hours after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and esophageal dilatation, which was successful. She experienced sudden onset chest discomfort that began after she got home, which has now worsened. She describes the pain as sharp and retrosternal. Her past medical history includes GERD, esophageal stricture, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Chest auscultation is clear bilaterally with evidence of crepitus noted over the left anterior chest wall extending up to the neck. Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. An electrocardiogram (EKG) shows sinus tachycardia without ST-segment or T-wave changes. Contrast esophagram shows a small limited leak. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and surgical consult

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of severe retrosternal chest pain after an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and esophageal dilatation. She has signs of subcutaneous emphysema, which is highly suggestive of esophageal perforation. Contrast esophagram confirms the diagnosis of a small contained leak from an esophageal perforation. Small contained leaks can be treated conservatively with IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consult for potential intervention.

Iatrogenic esophageal perforation following procedures is the most common cause of esophageal perforation, and it is associated with a high mortality rate. Chest X-ray can provide indirect evidence of an esophageal perforation (e.g. pneumomediastinum, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, or pleural effusions), but it cannot provide a definitive diagnosis. Contrast esohagram is used to diagnose an esophageal perforation. It can show extravasation of the contrast material, confirming the diagnosis and indicating the location of the perforation and extent of the leak. CT may also be used to make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Barium swallow study:
Incorrect: Barium should not be used in patients with suspected esophageal perforations because of the risk of barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum. This patient does not need further diagnostic studies.  
❌ Esophageal resection:
Incorrect: A conservative approach can be used to treat patients with esophageal perforations that result in small contained leaks. This includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consult for possible intervention.  
❌ Fundoplication:
Incorrect: A conservative approach can be used to treat patients with esophageal perforations that result in small contained leaks. This includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consult for possible intervention.  
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: This patient does not need further diagnostic studies.  
✅ IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and surgical consult:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the office because of heartburn following meals that she has been experiencing for the past 4 months. She has tried over-the-counter antacids without relief of symptoms. Her primary care physician recommended a two-week trial of ranitidine, which lessened the severity of her symptoms. However, once treatment was discontinued, her symptoms returned. She has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. Upper endoscopy reveals a proximal portion of the stomach herniating upward through the diaphragm. Which of the following additional findings would be expected given the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with refractory gastroesophageal reflux. The physical exam is benign, which is often the case with acid reflux and hiatal/paraesophageal hernias. Upper endoscopy shows part of the stomach herniating upward through the diaphragm, indicating a paraesophageal/hiatal hernia. Patients with paraesophageal/hiatal hernias with the stomach or other organs herniating through the hiatus into the chest cavity may experience limited lung expansion and dyspnea.       

Patients with type II paraesophageal hernias may be asymptomatic, or they may have vague, intermittent symptoms. The most common symptoms are epigastric or substernal pain, postprandial fullness, nausea, and retching. GERD symptoms are less prevalent as compared with patients with type I hernias. A gastric volvulus may occur with large paraesophageal hernias and can lead to dysphagia, postprandial pain, ischemia, and (rarely) strangulation.        

It is important to note that most patients with a hiatal/paraesophageal hernia will have a benign physical exam and will require additional workup with upper endoscopy or other modalities when there is suspicion for the diagnosis based on signs and symptoms.        

Option Analysis

❌ Hematemesis :
Incorrect: Chronic acid reflux may rarely lead to linear ulcerations which can cause blood-tinged emesis. Hematemesis is more often associated with esophageal varices, Boerhave syndrome, or Mallory-Weiss tears. This patient’s history and endoscopic findings are consistent with a  paraesophageal/hiatal hernia which on its own would not cause hematemesis.  
❌ Constipation  :
Incorrect: Constipation is a non-specific symptom that is not typically associated with paraesophageal/hiatal hernias. This patient’s history and endoscopic findings are consistent with a paraesophageal/ hiatal hernia. 
✅ Dyspnea  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Unintentional weight loss :
Incorrect: Unintentional weight loss is generally associated with malabsorptive disorders or malignancy. Weight loss is not typically seen in patients with paraesophageal hernias unless symptoms have persisted for months to years, which is not the case for this patient.  
❌ Left lower quadrant pain  :
Incorrect: Although patients who have paraesophageal/hiatal hernias may experience epigastric and/or upper abdominal pain and discomfort, left lower quadrant (LLQ) pain is typically not seen. LLQ pain is most often associated with diverticulitis or constipation. This patient’s history and endoscopic findings are consistent with a paraoesophageal/hiatal hernia.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of nausea, fatigue, forceful vomiting, and abdominal pain for 3 days. The child experienced an episode of hematemesis that morning and was brought in by her parents. She has not had fever, black stools, diarrhea, or mucous in stools. Family and past medical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 36.5 °C (97.7 °F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 87/46 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is lethargic and pale. Abdominal exam reveals epigastric tenderness without distention, rebound, guarding or rigidity. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge and follow-up in outpatient clinic

questions.solution:
This critically ill child presents with upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, pallor, tachycardia, and hypotension, and requires immediate volume resuscitation with intravenous fluids. In this patient, hematemesis was preceded by recurrent forceful vomiting, which can be seen with Mallory Weiss Syndrome.         

Mallory Weiss Syndrome is a condition where longitudinal mucosal lacerations in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach lead to upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The findings are usually caused by recurrent forceful vomiting. Patients often have a history of self-induced or frequent, forceful, non-bloody vomiting and epigastric pain followed by hematemesis. Physical exams typically reveal epigastric tenderness. It should be noted that in children, Mallory Weiss syndrome is rare; and therefore, blunt trauma secondary to abuse* should be ruled out.        

When a pediatric patient presents with hematemesis or melena, the first step is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if they are stable or unstable. Unstable patients should be stabilized with intravenous or intraosseous access and administration of intravenous fluids and packed red blood cells if necessary. Patients with brisk gastrointestinal bleeding can decompensate quickly and should be closely monitored for signs of hemorrhagic shock, such as tachycardia, hypotension, delayed capillary refill, and cool extremities. Placing a nasogastric tube with or without nasogastric lavage as needed should be considered. Once patients are stabilized, emergent endoscopy may be required for diagnostic or therapeutic interventions such as infusion of a proton pump inhibitor or octreotide.        

*P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

❌ Administer propranolol  :
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used to treat patients with upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding from liver disease and esophageal varices. This patient does present with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, but she is tachycardic and hypotensive and should first be stabilized by placing a peripheral intravenous catheter and initiating fluid resuscitation.  
❌ Discharge and follow-up in outpatient clinic  :
Incorrect: Discharge and follow-up are inappropriate for this unstable patient with likely upper gastrointestinal bleeding who requires stabilization. 
❌ Perform abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can help diagnose underlying liver disease in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. However, in this unstable patient with a likely gastrointestinal bleed, it is important to first stabilize the patient. 
❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy  :
Incorrect: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic for patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. However, it is important to first stabilize the patient before pursuing diagnostic testing. 
✅ Placement of intravenous catheter and fluid resuscitation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the trauma bay after a gunshot wound to the neck. Primary survey is intact, and secondary survey reveals two bullet wounds. One is 2cm superior and lateral to the sternal notch, and the other is on the posterolateral aspect of the neck. The patient is hemodynamically stable. The remainder of the secondary exam is unremarkable, and the bullet wounds are hemostatic. CT-A is obtained of the head, neck and chest which reveals no sign of laryngotracheal or vascular injury; however, there is soft tissue edema on the right anterior cervical esophagus. In addition, the patient has started to spit up bloody saliva. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a CXR to evaluate for pneumomediastinum
Transport to the operating room for exploration

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay after a penetrating neck injury (PNI) from a gunshot wound. The primary survey is intact, and the secondary survey does not reveal signs of hard or soft injury. Initial CT-A scan shows peri-esophageal soft tissue edema. This finding, in combination with bloody saliva and an anatomic Zone 1 wound, is suspicious for an esophageal injury. The next step in management is to obtain a gastrografin swallow evaluation.         

Although relatively uncommon, penetrating esophageal injuries are insidious, and delays in diagnosis carry mortality rates as high as 20 percent. Delays over 24 hours further increase the mortality rate. If pharyngoesophageal trauma is suspected, CT alone is inadequate for definitively ruling out injury, although it often identifies some signs of injury.       

Practice guidelines from the Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma (EAST) recommend that either endoscopy of the esophagus or esophagography be used to rule out significant esophageal injury in stable patients with PNI. If the patient can cooperate, a gastrografin or thin barium swallow can be performed first, and if nondiagnostic, flexible esophagoscopy can then be performed, increasing sensitivity to nearly 100 percent.    

Option Analysis

❌ Make NPO and observe for 24 hours :
Incorrect: In patients like this one with a suspected esophageal injury, delays in diagnosis significantly increase morbidity and mortality. This patient requires a diagnostic evaluation of the esophagus. 
❌ Obtain a CXR to evaluate for pneumomediastinum :
Incorrect: Pneumomediastinum would have been identified on CT-A scan, so CXR is unnecessary. While the presence of air in the mediastinum can suggest a pharyngoesophageal injury, it is not diagnostic and a diagnostic study like a gastrografin swallow evaluation should be performed. 
✅ Perform a gastrografin swallow evaluation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transport to the operating room for exploration :
Incorrect: In patients with hard signs of injury after a penetrating neck injury, operative exploration is the definitive management. However, this patient does not have hard or soft signs of injury, so operative exploration is unnecessary and further diagnostic imaging of the esophagus should be performed. 
❌ Perform a bronchoscopy :
Incorrect: In patients with suspected laryngotracheal injury, CT-A is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosis. In cases where CT is equivocal and an injury is suspected, a bronchoscopy or flexible nasopharyngosocpy can be performed. This patient does not have signs of a laryngotracheal injury and further evaluation of the esophagus should be performed.

questions.text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of feeding intolerance for the past 3 days. His parents state that he has had projectile vomiting with non-bloody and non-bilious emesis immediately after feeding. Previously, his feeding schedule and tolerance have been normal. He has had three wet diapers in the last 24 hours. Rectal temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, blood pressure is 85/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient has dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary examinations show no abnormalities. An olive-shaped mass is palpated in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following, if present, would be a known risk factor for the likely underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Second born child in the family birth order

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with projectile vomiting, feeding intolerance, and an olive-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant suggesting a diagnosis of pyloric stenosis. This patient is hemodynamically stable, though dehydrated with dry mucous membranes. The use of macrolide antibiotics is associated with increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis, particularly when these antibiotics are administered to infants younger than two weeks of age.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) refers to a disorder of young infants caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus, which can progress to near-complete obstruction of the gastric outlet and forceful vomiting. IHPS usually develops in patients between three and five weeks of age and rarely occurs after 12 weeks. It is more common among boys than girls. The vomiting is nonbilious and forceful ("projectile") (or may become more forceful over time), with associated weight loss if symptoms progress. While an "olive-like" mass may be palpated in the epigastric region or right upper quadrant, more often patients do not have this finding, especially if the diagnosis is made early.

Several risk factors are associated with IHPS including maternal smoking during pregnancy and bottle feeding. There is also a genetic component to IHPS, as approximately 6% of siblings of an affected patient develop IHPS. Patients who are firstborn have a higher risk of IHPS than those born later in the birth order. IHPS can also be associated with several other conditions, including hyperbilirubinemia, esophageal atresia, malrotation, and hypoplastic frenulum, so careful history should be obtained to rule out associated diagnoses.    

Option Analysis

❌ Rotavirus vaccination:
Incorrect:  Rotavirus vaccination is typically associated with an expansion of Peyer’s patches within the terminal ileum, which can create a lead point for intussusception. Patients with intussusception typically exhibit periods of intense abdominal pain followed by “red currant jelly” stools.  
❌ Exclusively breastfeeding:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with pyloric stenosis. Bottle feeding, unlike breastfeeding, is associated with an increased risk for pyloric stenosis. One study showed that bottle feeding during the first four months of life was associated with a more than fourfold increase in the risk of developing pyloric stenosis.  
✅ Macrolide antibiotic use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Second born child in the family birth order:
Incorrect: Being firstborn, not second born, has been associated with an increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis.  
❌ Full-term at birth:
Incorrect: Preterm birth increases the risk of pyloric stenosis. Full-term birth generally confers an advantage due to the ability to fully develop organ systems before birth.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the office after recent blood work which revealed a microcytic anemic (hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL). She has a past medical history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and atrial fibrillation and takes omeprazole, metoprolol, and apixaban. She has mild dyspnea with activity and occasional dysphagia with solids. She also has postprandial mid-epigastric pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a soft nontender abdomen without palpable masses. Chest x-ray shows a retrocardiac air-fluid level. Upper endoscopy reveals a foreshortened esophagus with the entire stomach herniated through the hiatus. A Cameron ulcer is seen at the level of the diaphragm. Colonoscopy shows no masses or polyps. Which of the following types of paraesophageal/hiatal hernia does this patient have?
questions.solution:
This 71-year-old woman presents with microcytic anemia, dyspnea, dysphagia with solid food, and post-prandial mid-epigastric pain. Chest X-ray shows a retrocardiac air-fluid level which is concerning for a paraesophageal/hiatal hernia. Given that this patient has microcytic anemia, upper and lower endoscopies are performed. Upper endoscopy showed a Cameron ulcer, the likely source of bleeding, and a foreshortened esophagus with herniation of the entire stomach, consistent with a type III hernia. A type III paraesophageal/hiatal hernia occurs when there is migration above the diaphragm of the GEJ and a portion of the stomach through the hiatus.        

Paraesophageal hernias can be diagnosed with upper endoscopy; however, barium swallow is the most sensitive diagnostic test. Barium swallow can determine the anatomy and size of the hernia, orientation of the stomach, and location of the GEJ. In patients with a paraesophageal /hernia, a retroflexed view on upper endoscopy will show a portion of the stomach herniating upward through the diaphragm adjacent to the endoscope.        

Esophageal manometry should be performed in patients diagnosed with paraesophageal/hiatal hernias for whom a wrapping of the stomach (fundoplication) will be performed. It measures the esophageal pressure and coordination at rest and with swallowing. The presence or absence of dysmotility is used to determine the type of fundoplication needed for operative repair.    



Option Analysis

❌ Type I  :
Incorrect: A type I paraesophageal/hiatal hernia or sliding hernia occurs when the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) migrates superiorly above the diaphragm.  
❌ Type II  :
Incorrect: A type II paraesophageal/hiatal hernia occurs when part of the gastric fundus has herniated through the hiatus with a normally located gastroesophageal junction (GEJ).  This patient has a foreshortened esophagus indicating that the GEJ has migrated upward, as well as indicating a type III hernia.  
✅ Type III  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type IV :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy shows herniation of the stomach and GEJ junction, but no other organs have herniated through the hiatus. This is consistent with Type III paraesophageal /hiatal hernia and not a type IV hernia. 
❌ Type V:
Incorrect: There are only 4 types of paraesophageal/hiatal hernias, and this patient has a type III hernia.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the primary care clinic with nausea and abdominal pain for one month. The pain localizes to the epigastrium and improves with eating and drinking milk. He has had two episodes of coffee ground emesis and one episode of black stool in the past 24 hours. The patient has not had diarrhea, mucous in stools, weight loss, or fever. Parents report he frequently takes ibuprofen for pain related to sports injuries. Family and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37° C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/61 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness, but no rigidity, rebound, or guarding. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis with mucosal lesions and a punched-out, smooth ulcer base. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Results      
 Hemoglobin       10.5 gm/dL     
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)      70 fL     
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH)      22 pg     
 Platelets       230,000 /μL     
 Prothrombin time (PT)      11     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT)      28
questions.solution:
This patient presents with epigastric pain, coffee ground emesis and melena and is found to have iron deficiency anemia. Endoscopy shows findings consistent with peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Peptic ulcer disease is commonly caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) which this patient has been taking. Treatment involves acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).   

PUD can be caused by Helicobacter pylori, NSAIDs, stressors like trauma or burns, and binge-drinking in adolescents. Complications of PUD include upper gastrointestinal bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, and perforation. Patients usually report retrosternal chest or epigastric pain and dyspepsia that may improve after eating, milk consumption, or antacids. Physical exam may be normal but may reveal epigastric tenderness. Upper endoscopy may show erythema, erosions, or subepithelial hemorrhage of the gastric mucosa with ulceration. In addition to addressing the underlying cause (e.g., stopping NSAIDs, antibiotics for H. pylori), treatment of peptic ulcer disease involves acid suppression using proton pump inhibitors.   

Option Analysis

❌ Endoscopic band ligation :
Incorrect: Endoscopic band ligation is used to treat acutely bleeding esophageal varices. This patient has no history of liver disease and is stable. The findings on endoscopy are consistent with peptic ulcer disease for which proton pump inhibitors are the most appropriate treatment. 
❌ Intravenous octreotide infusion  :
Incorrect: Octreotide is used to treat gastrointestinal bleeding from esophageal varices. However, the findings on this patient’s endoscopy are consistent with peptic ulcer disease. 
❌ Observation for one month :
Incorrect: This patient presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and iron deficiency anemia likely secondary to peptic ulcer disease from ibuprofen use. Treatment with proton pump inhibitors should be initiated. 
✅ Oral proton pump inhibitors :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Packed red blood cell transfusion :
Incorrect: Packed red blood cell transfusion is indicated in patients with acute gastrointestinal bleeding when they are hemodynamically unstable or have severe anemia. This patient is clinically stable with mildly decreased hemoglobin, and findings consistent with peptic ulcer disease, for which proton pump inhibitors should be started.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of excessive fatigue and shortness of breath. He has also unintentionally lost 12-lb (5.4 kg) in the past 2 months. He has not had abdominal pain, melena, or changes in bowel habits. He has not visited a physician in many years, but he was urged by his partner to make an appointment. The patient recently retired from a battery-manufacturing factory, which he worked at for 35 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for skin and conjunctival pallor. Laboratory results are as follows:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.8 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40% 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  74 μm3 

Which of the following diagnostic studies would be most helpful in confirming this patient’s underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly male is presenting with fatigue, dyspnea, and conjunctival pallor. Laboratory testing is notable for microcytic anemia (decreased hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume). These findings are likely due to iron-deficiency anemia secondary to a gastrointestinal malignancy. A colonoscopy should be performed to evaluate for underlying colorectal cancer.  

The symptoms of colon cancer vary depending on its location. Right-sided colon cancers often cause chronic occult bleeding, resulting in iron-deficiency anemia. In contrast to left-sided colon cancers, right-sided tumors do not typically cause obstruction, since the right-sided colon has a larger diameter than the left.  

Left-sided colon cancers, in contrast, tend to have a different presentation. They are usually smaller, but as they infiltrate the wall of the colon, the cancer can encircle the lumen and cause significant narrowing. As a result, patients with left-sided colon cancers typically present with signs of obstruction, such as narrowing of stool (“pencil-thin stools”), colicky pains, constipation, and abdominal distension. In some cases, left-sided colon cancer can cause hematochezia, which is the passage of fresh, bright red blood through the anus.


Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid function studies:
Incorrect: Although this patient is presenting with excessive fatigue, which can also be seen in patients with hypothyroidism, the other presenting symptoms and laboratory findings (e.g., pallor, anemia) cannot be fully explained by hypothyroidism alone. 
❌ Chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Although this patient has a significant smoking history and recent weight loss, he does not have the chronic cough or hemoptysis typically seen in lung cancer.
❌ Serum lead levels:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning can be seen in patients who have had chronic exposure to the substance, such as those working in battery manufacturing plants. Lead poisoning typically manifests with abdominal pain, constipation, and cognitive impairments. However, none of these symptoms are present in this patient. 
❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used for further evaluation in patients suspected of having thalassemia or sickle cell trait/disease. However, these conditions would typically manifest with symptoms in childhood. It would be unusual for any of these conditions to first present with symptoms in a 61-year-old.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and severe abdominal pain since yesterday. He has had 4-5 episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea per day accompanied by lower abdominal cramps for the past 2 months. Review of systems reveals a 4-kg (8.8-lbs) weight loss and loss of appetite. The remainder of his history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows lethargy and dry mucous membranes. There is abdominal distension, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and decreased bowel sounds without rebound or guarding. Rectal examination reveals marked tenderness, with guaiac-positive, maroon-colored, liquid stools in the vault. Laboratory results are shown below:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9.9 mg/dL 
 Platelets  455,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes  19,200/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  67 mm/hr 

 Fluid resuscitation with 0.9% normal saline improves the blood pressure to 103/59 mmHg. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a 2-month history of multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea that are accompanied by abdominal cramps likely has undiagnosed inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis (UC). His rapid clinical deterioration (severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, tenesmus) with signs of shock (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension, lethargy) are concerning for toxic megacolon, a known complication of UC.

Toxic megacolon is a result of worsening inflammation of the bowel that causes release of inflammatory mediators (e.g. cytokines), bacterial products, and increased amounts of nitric oxide, which contributes to colonic smooth muscle paralysis. This paralysis not only disrupts the intestinal motility but also causes thinning of the intestinal wall and colonic distension, making it prone to perforation. Other manifestations include altered mental status, signs of peritonitis (in the event of perforation), and electrolyte abnormalities.

The diagnosis of toxic megacolon can be made on plain abdominal x-ray, a non-invasive study that can be quickly performed and also rules out mechanical obstruction or perforation. It shows colonic dilation (diameter >6 cm) with multiple air-fluid levels. If these findings are accompanied by free air under the diaphragm, intestinal perforation should be considered.


Retrieved from: Radiopaedia.org



Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Though high-resolution ultrasound is helpful in assessing the response to therapy in patients with UC, it is not typically used in the diagnosis of toxic megacolon. It is usually employed in acute trauma (to look for intraperitoneal free fluid), acute right upper quadrant pain (e.g. due to cholecystitis), or suspected nephrolithiasis.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon due to the risk of perforation. However, sigmoidoscopy (without bowel preparation) or proctoscopy can be considered to help identify the etiology of colonic dilation once the diagnosis is confirmed with abdominal x-ray.
❌ Barium enema:
Incorrect: Though helpful in the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, barium enema is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon due to the risk of perforation.  
✅ Plain abdominal x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Opioid analgesics:
Incorrect: Opioid analgesics are contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon as they further reduce the bowel motility, thereby increasing the risk of perforation. Antimotility agents (e.g. loperamide) and anticholinergic drugs should also be avoided.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the office with complaints of frequent loose stools and abdominal pain. He started having these symptoms a month ago, and they did not respond to over-the-counter antidiarrheals. He became concerned when he noticed an increase in urgency and a small amount of blood admixed with mucoid stools yesterday. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has not recently travelled outside the country. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild abdominal tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Colonoscopy shows erythematous rectal mucosa that is friable to touch, along with scattered ulcerations extending up to the distal part of sigmoid colon. The remainder of the colon and ileum are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for the patient at this stage?
questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent episodes of diarrhea that has recently become bloody and abdominal pain. The colonoscopy findings of continuous rectal and sigmoid colon inflammation and ulceration, together with erythematous bowel walls and friable mucosa, are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Clinically, it presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Treatment of UC depends on disease severity, how much of the colon is involved, and the frequency of disease relapse or flares. Mild-to-moderate UC is initially treated with a 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) suppository or enema. Oral formulation of 5-ASA is added if the patient doesn’t respond to the topical treatment. Another alternative is the addition of oral glucocorticoid preparation, which also helps in alleviating the inflammation and in achieving remission. In severe cases unresponsive to these agents, anti-tumor necrosis factor agents (e.g. infliximab) can be tried.




Option Analysis

❌ Oral budesonide:
Incorrect: Budesonide is a glucocorticoid oral formulation which is usually employed in the treatment of mild-to-moderate UC that is unresponsive to oral and topical 5-ASA. It is one of the initial treatment modalities in the treatment of Crohn disease. In this patient, however, a trial of 5-ASA suppository should be tried first.
❌ Oral infliximab:
Incorrect: Biologic agents (e.g. infliximab) are usually considered as an initial therapy in patients with severe or fulminant UC who cannot tolerate glucocorticoids. These can also be considered in patients with mild-to-moderate Crohn disease. This patient with mild UC does not qualify for infliximab therapy.
✅ 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) suppository:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Intravenous methylprednisolone is the cornerstone of treatment of acute severe (fulminant) UC. It is also used in the management of IBD-related toxic megacolon. It is not preferred for long term management of mild UC and may cause unwanted side effects (e.g., Cushing syndrome, osteoporosis).
❌ Intravenous cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Cyclosporine is an anti-metabolite commonly used in patients with renal transplantation. It is reserved for the management of acute severe UC who fail to improve within three to five days of intravenous glucocorticoids.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of persistent fevers, fatigue, loss of appetite, and transient chest pain for the past 2 months. He has also unintentionally lost 7 kg (15 lb) over the same time period. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Physical examination is non-contributory. Serial blood cultures grow Streptococcus gallolyticus. Echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve. Once the patient is stabilized and treated for his bacteremia, which of the following additional diagnostic tests should be performed?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of low-grade fevers, weight loss, and vegetations seen on the mitral valve. These findings, along with positive blood cultures growing Streptococcus gallolyticus (also termed Streptococcus bovis biotype I), are suggestive of infective endocarditis and potentially an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy.       
Streptococcus bovis (S. bovis) is a bacteria commonly found in the human gastrointestinal tract, but its presence in the bloodstream is strongly associated with colorectal cancer. However, not all genospecies are equally related to the disease. A recent meta-analysis on the association between S. bovis biotypes and colonic adenomas/carcinomas revealed that patients with S. bovis biotype I bacteremia had a greater risk of having colorectal cancer than those with S. bovis biotype II bacteremia.    

The main site of entry for S. bovis into the bloodstream is the GI tract. Thus, given the association between the pathogen and colorectal cancer, patients should undergo colonoscopy for evaluation of an underlying occult malignancy.

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy :
Incorrect: The original blood cultures grew Streptococcus bovis, a bacteria common to the gastrointestinal tract. The presence of S. bovis in the bloodstream should raise concerns for underlying colon cancer, which can be evaluated via colonoscopy, not upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy. 
❌ Chest CT scan:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, further diagnostic work-up of the gastrointestinal tract should be performed. Performing a CT scan of the chest would not be helpful and would do little to guide this patient’s care. 
❌ Cystoscopy:
Incorrect: The genitourinary tract is commonly colonized by Enterococcal species. Therefore, patients who have recently undergone a cystoscopy may be at a higher risk of enterococcal endocarditis. However, performing a cystoscopy is unlikely to reveal an underlying condition that caused this patient’s initial bacteremia. 
❌ Abdominal CT scan:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract. Although an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy is likely in this patient, a different diagnostic modality should be used.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. She has no changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Her previous colonoscopy 10 years ago showed no abnormalities. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of colorectal cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, which reveals a single, sessile 10-mm polyp covered in mucous in the ascending colon. Histology of this polyp subtype from a different patient is shown below:  

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up colonoscopy in 5 years

questions.solution:
Colorectal polyps are overgrowths of epithelial cells in the colon or rectum. They are subdivided into non-neoplastic polyps (e.g., hamartomatous polyps, hyperplastic polyps, inflammatory pseudopolyps) and neoplastic polyps (e.g., adenomatous polyps, serrated polyps). Serrated polyps are a type of colonic polyp that has moderate potential to undergo malignant transformation and therefore should be treated with complete excision.    

Serrated polyps, also termed sessile serrated adenomas (SSAs), are commonly seen in the right colon. These polyps have a smooth surface, are often flat or sessile, and may be covered with mucus. The most useful histologic feature that distinguishes SSAs from hyperplastic polyps is the presence of serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands, including the crypt base (Figure 1). In contrast, hyperplastic polyps have serrated architecture only at the surface. This unique architecture often gives serrated polyps a “sawtooth” appearance under the microscope.

 Figure 1: Histological differences between hyperplastic and serrated polyps  


A) Hyperplastic polyps demonstrate serrated architecture primarily at the surface (Wikimedia Commons)
B) Serrated polyps demonstrate serrate architecture through the full length of the biopsy sample (Wikimedia Commons)

Option Analysis

✅ Complete excision of the polyp:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetic testing for MLH1 mutations:
Incorrect: Lynch syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2). Lynch syndrome is unlikely in this patient who has no family history of colorectal cancer and no personal history of abnormal colonoscopies.
❌ Genetic testing for STK11 mutations:
Incorrect: Peutz-Jegher syndrome is caused by a mutation in the STK11 gene. It presents with mucosal hyperpigmentation and numerous hamartomatous gastrointestinal polyps in young children. This patient is presenting with a single colonic polyp at a much older age and had no abnormalities noted on previous colonoscopies, hence making Peutz-Jegher syndrome unlikely. 
❌ Genetic testing for APC mutations:
Incorrect: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder marked by the appearance of numerous colorectal adenomas by the teenage years. This patient lacks a familial history of colon cancer, and her previous colonoscopy yielded normal findings, hence making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Observation and follow-up colonoscopy in 5 years:
Incorrect: The histological findings are consistent with those of a serrated polyp. Serrated polyps have a moderate risk for malignant transformation and therefore should be immediately excised.

A 22-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of recurrent episodes of bloating and diarrhea that typically occur after eating. These symptoms began four months ago. During this time, he has had an unintentional 12-lb weight loss and developed a pruritic rash over his bilateral forearms. He was hospitalized 2 years ago after a motor vehicle accident, during which he experienced an episode of anaphylactic shock after receiving a blood transfusion. The patient has no recent history of travel. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. There are multiple tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the bilateral elbows and dorsal forearms. He has mild tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. Laboratory studies from his previous hospitalization are shown below:
 
 Immunoglobulins, serum 
 IgA  10 mg/dL (Normal: 76-390 mg/dL) 
 IgG  1200 mg/dL (Normal: 650-1500 mg/dL) 
 IgM  325 mg/dL (Normal: 40-345 mg/dL) 

Which of the following tests would be the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Stool analysis for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of celiac disease (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss, dermatitis herpetiformis), and he also likely has selective IgA deficiency. Celiac disease is highly associated with selective IgA deficiency, which explains his previous episode of anaphylaxis after receiving a blood transfusion.

In patients with suspected celiac disease, serum tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTG-IgA) antibody titers should be obtained. This titer is the single preferred test for detecting celiac disease in adults. However, in patients with IgA deficiency, IgG-based testing with deamidated gliadin peptide IgG (DGP-IgG) is performed instead to prevent false negative results.

If a patient has symptoms consistent with celiac disease and positive antibody titers, then an intestinal biopsy via endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ IgG deamidated gliadin peptide titers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody titers:
Incorrect: Measuring IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase titers is an excellent diagnostic test for celiac disease. However, this patient likely has selective IgA deficiency given his laboratory results and the history of an anaphylactic reaction after a blood product transfusion. Therefore, testing for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies would likely result in a false negative result.
❌ Stool analysis for ova and parasites:
Incorrect: Testing the stool for ova and parasites is a good initial diagnostic tool for patients presenting with diarrhea. However, this patient has not traveled recently, and his clinical signs of dermatitis herpetiformis and selective IgA deficiency are more indicative of celiac disease.
❌ Fecal elastase measurement:
Incorrect: Fecal elastase measurement is a good screening test for patients suspected of having pancreatic insufficiency. Although this patient is presenting with steatorrhea, he lacks the risk factors associated with pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., chronic alcohol use, recurrent episodes of pancreatitis).
❌ Hydrogen breath test:
Incorrect: A hydrogen breath test is an excellent screening tool for patients suspected of having lactose intolerance. Although this patient is presenting with episodes of bloating and diarrhea after eating, he has other clinical and laboratory findings that cannot be explained by lactose intolerance alone.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic because of a 3-month history of bloody diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Her symptoms have been progressing and she has been having 5 episodes of loose bloody stool per day for the past month. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.3 °C (99.1 °F), blood pressure is 142/85, pulse is 92/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient appears comfortable. Physical examination is significant for moderate abdominal tenderness on palpation and bright red blood on digital rectal exam. Laboratory findings are significant for a hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL and an elevated CRP. Stool studies are negative for infectious etiologies. Fecal calprotectin is positive. A colonoscopy reveals a continuous pattern of erythema, friability, and ulcerations in the rectum and sigmoid colon. Histopathological examination reveals mucosal and submucosal chronic inflammation, and crypt abscesses consistent with the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Which of the following medications should be administered to induce remission in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 3-month history of bloody diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, and a positive fecal calprotectin, highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC), which was confirmed by a colonoscopy with biopsies. Given the 1-month history of 5 loose bloody stools per day, the absence of signs of systemic toxicity, and the presence of mild anemia and elevated CRP on laboratory studies, this patient’s disease can be classified as moderate-to-severe.    

The treatment goal of UC is to achieve glucocorticoid-free clinical and endoscopic remission of disease. Treatment can be divided into induction and maintenance therapy, both of which are dictated by the severity of the disease and the response to treatment.    

For patients with moderate-to-severe UC, first-line induction and maintenance therapy consist of monoclonal anti-TNF-alpha antibodies (e.g., adalimumab, golimumab, infliximab). If remission is not achieved, the second-line induction therapy options include adding oral corticosteroids (e.g. prednisone) ± thiopurine immunomodulators (e.g. 6-mercaptopurine) added to the previous treatment, or switching to other types of monoclonal antibodies such as anti-integrins (e.g. vedolizumab) or JAK inhibitors (e.g. tofacitinib). If remission is induced, glucocorticoids are tapered off while continuing the same medical therapy.    

For patients with mild-to-moderate UC, both induction and maintenance therapy consist of 5-aminosalicylate agents, given locally (e.g., suppositories, enema) or orally depending on the extent of colon involvement. If 5-ASA fails to induce remission, second-line induction therapy consists of adding local corticosteroids which are then tapered off if remission is achieved or switched to systemic corticosteroids if remission is not induced.    

For patients with acute severe UC, first-line induction therapy is systemic IV corticosteroids, which are later replaced by monoclonal anti-TNF-alpha antibodies (e.g. infliximab) ± thiopurine immunomodulators (e.g., 6-MP, AZA) if remission is achieved. If remission is not attained with IV-corticosteroids, second-line induction therapy involves adding a monoclonal anti-TNF-alpha antibody (e.g. infliximab) or cyclosporine to the previous treatment. Maintenance therapy then involves gradually reducing the corticosteroids and modifying the medications used during the induction phase.    

Colectomy is indicated if ulcerative colitis is unresponsive to medical treatment, or complicated by toxic megacolon, perforation, or massive refractory rectal bleeding.    

A follow-up colonoscopy should be scheduled for all patients with active UC 6-12 months after clinical remission, regardless of disease severity.   

Option Analysis

✅ TNF-alpha inhibitors  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 5-aminosalicylates  :
Incorrect: 5-aminosalicylates (5-ASA) are considered first-line treatment for induction therapy in mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis. This patient has evidence of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis; therefore, TNF-alpha inhibitors are indicated.  
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are added to the management of patients with mild-to-moderate or moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis (UC) that do not respond to first-line therapy; they are also considered first-line treatment for induction therapy in acute severe ulcerative colitis. This patient has evidence of moderate-to-severe UC that has not yet been treated, and therefore, TNF-alpha inhibitors are indicated.  
❌ JAK inhibitors:
Incorrect: JAK inhibitors are considered second line treatment for induction therapy in moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis (UC) if TNF-alpha inhibitors fail to induce remission. This patient has evidence of moderate-to-severe UC that has not yet been treated; therefore, TNF-alpha inhibitors are indicated.  
❌ Cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Cyclosporine is added to the management of patients with acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC) that does not respond to first-line treatment. This patient has evidence of moderate-severe ulcerative colitis and TNF-alpha inhibitors are indicated.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and peripheral vascular disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. He describes crampy abdominal pain after meals for the past 6 months. This has been accompanied by decreased appetite and a 15 lb weight loss. However, his pain today is much more severe. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8 °F), blood pressure is 70/38 mmHg, pulse is 128/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On examination, he is in significant distress. His abdomen is mildly distended, with diffuse tenderness to palpation and guarding. Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of vascular disease (e.g., coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease) and symptoms of long-standing, crampy abdominal pain and weight loss are consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI). Additionally, he is presenting with worsening pain, guarding on examination, hypotension, and tachycardia. These findings are concerning for potential acute complications, such as infarction and perforation.

CMI occurs when there is decreased blood flow within the mesenteric vasculature, often due to narrowing of the blood vessels by atherosclerotic plaques. Symptoms, such as abdominal pain, classically occur after meals since the intestines have a higher demand for perfusion during this period.

The first step in evaluating a patient presenting with CMI is to perform an ABCDE assessment. If the patient is found to be unstable, acute management should be initiated. This may include oxygen, intubation, IV fluids, obtaining IV access, cardiopulmonary monitoring, and starting empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Once these measures are underway, further workup to evaluate for bowel infarction, with laboratory studies (e.g., lactate) and abdominal imaging, can be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV fluid bolus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Norepinephrine infusion:
Incorrect: Vasopressors, such as norepinephrine, can be used to maintain blood pressure in cases of shock. However, they can worsen cases of mesenteric ischemia, making them contraindicated in this setting.  
❌ Pantoprazole:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors, such as pantoprazole, can be used in cases of upper GI bleeding or suspected peptic ulcer disease. However, this patient’s history is more consistent with acute-on-chronic mesenteric ischemia, which requires emergent stabilizing measures.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Antiplatelet therapy, such as aspirin, is used in the management of stable, chronic mesenteric ischemia. However, this patient requires emergent stabilization.  
❌ Angiography:
Incorrect: Angiography is a diagnostic tool for mesenteric ischemia. However, this patient’s hemodynamic instability should be addressed first.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office to be evaluated for recurrent episodes of epigastric bloating and crampy pain. The pain usually begins after eating and is relieved by vomiting or lying on her stomach. The patient is a dancer and joined a training program a few months ago. She has lost 30-lbs (13.6 kg) over the past two months while on a “crash diet.” Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended and tender abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. A plain abdominal x-ray reveals findings suggestive of proximal small bowel obstruction. The upper gastrointestinal series demonstrates a marked delay in the passage of the contrast from the duodenum into the more distal small bowel. The delay resolves when the patient takes a knee-chest position. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of recurrent epigastric pain aggravated with food consumption and relieved with vomiting or lying prone, combined with the imaging findings, are consistent with superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome.   

The SMA typically leaves the aorta at an angle of 45 degrees. If the angle diminishes to an angle less than 22 degrees, the transverse portion of the duodenum can get entrapped between the SMA and aorta, leading to symptoms of partial bowel obstruction.    

Acute loss of mesenteric fat (e.g., recent weight loss, low body weight, severe burns, and prolonged bed rest) is thought to permit the artery to drop posteriorly, trapping the bowel and causing an intermittent obstruction. It can also occur in patients with pronounced lordosis or after surgical correction of scoliosis, as this procedure lengthens the spine resulting in decreased mobility of SMA.  

Patients often have epigastric bloating and crampy pain, particularly after eating that may be relieved with vomiting. The symptoms may resolve with the patient in the prone, left lateral decubitus, or a knee-chest position, which increases the angle between the SMA and the aorta. It may present acutely with signs and symptoms of small bowel obstruction or chronically with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, vague abdominal symptoms, and early satiety. Physical examination may show abdominal distension, a succussion splash, and high-pitched bowel sounds. The diagnosis is established based on clinical features and noninvasive imaging that demonstrates an abnormal angle between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transmural inflammation of the intestine:
Incorrect: Transmural inflammation of the intestine is seen in Crohn disease. Patients typically present with chronic right lower quadrant pain (not epigastric pain) and other constitutional symptoms. Moreover, the delayed passage of contrast via the duodenum suggests duodenal compression.  
❌ Intermittent increase of intra-gallbladder pressure:
Incorrect: Biliary colic occurs as the gallbladder contracts against an obstructing stone, leading to an intermittent increase of intra-gallbladder pressure. The pain is typically episodic and is located in the right upper quadrant.   
❌ Progressive pancreatic inflammation:
Incorrect: Pain accompanied by malabsorption may be due to chronic pancreatitis. It is, however, an unlikely diagnosis in the absence of risk factors (e.g. heavy alcohol use). An abdominal x-ray may show pancreatic calcification.  
✅ Duodenal compression between arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves:
Incorrect: Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves is thought to be the underlying cause of irritable bowel syndrome. Weight loss and recurrent epigastric pain with bloating relieved with vomiting in this patient suggest an alternative underlying cause.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the primary care office with three days of abdominal bloating. The patient recently moved to a new house and has been eating takeout food for dinner frequently. The patient reports it has been more difficult to have a bowel movement than usual, and it requires him to strain significantly. The last bowel movement was two days ago, and he reports it was the only one he has had this week. Past surgical history is significant for an appendectomy at age 28. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mmHg. The abdomen is soft with mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant on deep palpation. Which of the following is the most important feature to ask about in order to determine if there is an associated bowel obstruction?

choices.text: Use of manual maneuvers to help move stool out of the rectum
Feeling of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of constipation, including difficulty passing stools and infrequent passing of stool. When evaluating a patient with new onset constipation, it is important to ask about the ability to pass gas since obstipation (inability to pass stool and gas) can be a sign of bowel obstruction, which may require supportive care and surgery.

Constipation occurs when stool is unable to move through the bowel properly and/or the pelvic muscles or anal sphincter are unable to facilitate adequate emptying. This may lead to straining with defecation, infrequent bowel movements, a feeling of incomplete emptying, and needing to use manual maneuvers to defecate. Hard stools are a common feature of constipation and the Bristol stool chart can be used to help patients describe their stool objectively based on shape and texture. Abdominal discomfort and bloating may be present. Having less than three bowel movements per week is also suggestive of constipation, although not required for diagnosis.

Physical examination in patients presenting with constipation should include visual inspection of the anal area and a digital rectal exam (DRE). Common findings on DRE are a palpable stool ball or fecal impaction. Patients should be asked to “bear down” or strain as if trying to have a bowel movement during the exam to allow for assessment of sphincter tone and the strength of surrounding musculature. Abnormalities of the sphincter or musculature may suggest an underlying neurologic etiology. Finally, patients should be assessed for anal fissures, hemorrhoids, masses, tenderness, or strictures during the DRE and visual exam.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hard stools:
Incorrect: Hard stools are common in constipation and would not indicate bowel obstruction.  
❌ Use of manual maneuvers to help move stool out of the rectum:
Incorrect: Needing to use manual maneuvers for stool evacuation is common in constipation; however, it would not be suggestive of a bowel obstruction.  
✅ Ability to pass gas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Feeling of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements:
Incorrect: A feeling of incomplete emptying is common in constipation and would not indicate a large bowel obstruction.  
❌ Date of last colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy history may help in making the differential diagnosis and evaluating constipation, but it would not help determine if a bowel obstruction is present.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the clinic with crampy abdominal pain and non-bloody watery diarrhea. He has had similar episodes during the past seven months. He says his symptoms occur after eating regardless of the type of food he eats, and the pain is relieved following defecation. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. He has no family history of gastrointestinal malignancies. He has not traveled recently, has no food allergies, does not smoke, consumes alcohol occasionally, and does not use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals mild, diffuse, non-radiating epigastric tenderness on palpation. Perianal and rectal examination are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show a normal CBC and a negative tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTg-IgA). Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Initiate a high fiber, low carbohydrate diet

questions.solution:
This patient’s seven-month history of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain relieved by defecation without evidence of underlying organic pathology is strongly suggestive of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)-D. IBS is defined as a chronic bowel condition that requires at least three-months of symptoms and is characterized by recurrent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both). Initial management of patients with mild to moderate IBS is with lifestyle and dietary modifications, which include increasing soluble fiber intake, eating a low carbohydrate diet, and increasing physical activity.

Certain high carbohydrate foods, such as potatoes, brown rice, oats, and almonds, should be avoided. Additionally FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) can be limited or avoided.

If initial management of IBS with dietary modifications is unsuccessful or in patients with severe symptoms, pharmacologic agents can be prescribed based on the subtype and the predominant symptoms as detailed in the table below. The treatment goal for IBS-D is to increase stool firmness and decrease bowel movement frequency. This can be accomplished by using TCAS (which can slow GI transit), cholestyramine, non-absorbed antibiotics (e.g. rifaximin) or mixed opioid agonist-antagonists (e.g. eluxadoline).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate a high fiber, low carbohydrate diet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eliminate gluten-containing foods:
Incorrect: Gluten-sensitive enteropathy, or Celiac disease, is an immune-mediated inflammatory gastrointestinal disease that is caused by sensitivity to gluten-containing foods. Eliminating these foods usually resolves symptoms associated with Celiac disease. Since this patient has a negative tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTg-IgA), this is not appropriate management.  
❌ Eliminate lactose-containing foods:
Incorrect: Lactose intolerance presents with abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, nausea, or diarrhea following ingestion of lactose containing products. Given the lack of these symptoms, this patient is not lactose intolerant and would not benefit from eliminating lactose-containing foods.  
❌ Start antimicrobial therapy:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms have persisted for seven months. He has no history of recent travel, is afebrile, and has a normal CBC, which does not support a diagnosis of infectious diarrhea.  
❌ Cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: Acute cholecystitis commonly presents with right upper quadrant pain (+/- radiation), fever, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Given the lack of these findings and the chronicity of this patient’s condition, cholecystectomy is not indicated.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was recently admitted to hospice care. The patient is frail, does not ambulate often, and receives several palliative medications for pain secondary to late-stage colon cancer, including morphine and fentanyl. The patient has no difficulty or discomfort with bowel movements, and cancer-related pain is well-controlled. The patient eats 3 meals per day and has a bowel movement 3 times per week. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical exam findings are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate daily treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Laxatives are substances that ease the passage of fecal matter from the rectum, while cathartics have a much stronger effect and cause the evacuation of stool from the entire colon. Cathartics such as sorbitol, magnesium citrate, magnesium hydroxide, sodium phosphate, or sodium sulfate cause an osmotic imbalance which draws water into the large bowel lumen. Cathartics are often used as bowel prep agents for colonoscopy or surgical prep. Others, like polyethylene glycol (not to be confused with ethylene glycol, in antifreeze), can be used for daily maintenance or to help facilitate the disimpaction of bowel contents in severely constipated patients. Overuse of some cathartics can cause severe dehydration and acute kidney injury (as some magnesium is reabsorbed). In the case of this frail 75-year-old patient on hospice care, a cathartic would be inappropriate due to the increased risk of dehydration. In addition, a stimulating agent would be more appropriate since his stools are not hard or difficult to pass.
