Senna is a stimulant laxative which is often prescribed with docusate, an emollient laxative. Stimulant laxatives act by directly stimulating the intestinal mucosa and producing peristalsis. Emollient laxatives act as a surfactant by decreasing the surface tension of water, allowing water to soften stool. Senna/docusate is typically prescribed as a combination when initiating opioid therapy in order to prevent opioid-induced constipation. However, the effectiveness of docusate is being called into question more and more, and senna alone may be equally effective. First-line therapy for most causes of constipation includes patient education, exercise, dietary modification, and a bulking laxative such as psyllium (see table below).
 



Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium citrate:
Incorrect: Laxatives are substances that ease the passage of fecal matter from the rectum, while cathartics have a much stronger effect and cause the evacuation of stool from the entire colon. Cathartics such as magnesium citrate, magnesium sulfate, magnesium hydroxide, sodium phosphate, sodium sulfate or sorbitol cause an osmotic imbalance which draws water into the large bowel lumen. Overuse of cathartics can cause severe dehydration and renal impairment (as some magnesium is reabsorbed). For this frail 75-year-old patient on hospice care, a cathartic agent is excessive and will risk dehydrating the patient.  
❌ Decreasing opioid use:
Incorrect: An important cause of constipation in elderly and hospitalized adults is opioid use. Approximately 40-60% of non-cancer patients who use opioids develop opioid-induced constipation (OIC). While reducing opioids will eventually reduce constipation, it is not appropriate to withhold pain medication for patients with proper indications (such as hospice care). A faster and more appropriate therapy typically involves starting the use of a stimulant laxative (such as senna) with or without a stool softener (such as docusate) when opioids are first administered to prevent OIC (1,2).  
✅ Senna:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glycerin:
Incorrect: Glycerin is an emollient laxative. It acts as a surfactant, decreasing the surface tension of water, allowing water to penetrate and soften the stool, but it has no direct impact on bowel motility. In this patient’s case the stools are not hard or difficult to pass, so stimulating the bowels rather than softening the stool would be more appropriate.  
❌ Sorbitol:
Incorrect: Sorbitol is a cathartic agent which increases the osmotic gradient, drawing water into the large bowel lumen. Cathartics can be used for constipation, and are more commonly used as bowel prep agents for colonoscopy or surgery. A significant adverse effect of cathartics is dehydration and acute kidney injury (as some magnesium from magnesium-based cathartics is reabsorbed). For this frail 75-year-old patient on hospice care, a cathartic agent is excessive and will risk dehydrating the patient.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for nausea, vomiting, abdominal bloating, and pain after eating. Symptoms have occurred for the past month and are accompanied by night sweats. She had been passing gas and having infrequent stools but hasn’t had a bowel movement for 3 days. She has been taking over-the-counter antacids as well as using marijuana to try to improve the nausea without significant relief. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus. She typically smokes one marijuana cigarette over a weekend every few months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 98/62 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Weight is 140lb (63.5 kg), down from 152lb (68.9 kg) at a visit two months ago. On exam, the patient appears fatigued and pale. Abdominal examination shows mild distension and high-pitched bowel sounds. There is mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. An upright abdominal radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Image by Igboeze is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license. Reproduced from WikiCommons

choices.text: Computed tomography scan of the head

questions.solution:
This patient has been experiencing chronic nausea and vomiting, accompanied by abdominal bloating and pain, and is found to have abdominal distention and tenderness on exam. Imaging shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels consistent with small bowel obstruction. She has likely had a partial obstruction that has become complete. Surgery should be consulted to determine the best treatment. This patient’s weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats are concerning for cancer as the underlying cause of the obstruction.

Chronic vomiting can be caused by a variety of etiologies, some of which require urgent medical or surgical intervention. Patients presenting with chronic vomiting should first be assessed for stability, as vomiting can cause life-threatening disturbances in electrolytes, acid-base disturbances, and severe volume depletion. Stable patients should next be assessed for urgent conditions affecting the abdomen or brain. Bowel obstruction is an urgent abdominal cause of vomiting that requires prompt management. The obstruction may be partial or complete depending on the degree of intestinal blockage. Common causes of obstruction include adhesions from prior abdominal surgeries, cancer, and hernias. Abdominal CT is the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis of a bowel obstruction. Management includes nasogastric tube insertion for bowel decompression, with or without surgical intervention, depending on the underlying cause and degree of the obstruction.    

Option Analysis

✅ Consult surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recommend discontinuation of marijuana:
Incorrect: Frequent chronic use of marijuana can lead to vomiting; however, this patient has findings consistent with bowel obstruction, which would account for her symptoms. Additionally, patients with cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome typically have chronic daily use of marijuana whereas this patient's use is occasional. 
❌ Computed tomography scan of the head:
Incorrect: A computed tomography scan of the head may be indicated in cases of chronic vomiting where a neurological process is suspected. This patient has abdominal symptoms and findings of small bowel obstruction on imaging that would explain her vomiting. 
❌ Administer polyethylene glycol:
Incorrect: Polyethylene glycol can be helpful in the management of constipation; however, this patient has evidence of a mechanical bowel blockage and polyethylene glycol is contraindicated.  
❌ Administer metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide can be used to treat nausea, however, this patient has evidence of a bowel obstruction causing nausea, vomiting, and crampy abdominal pain after eating. Given metoclopramide’s prokinetic properties, it is contraindicated in this patient with a bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past several weeks. There is associated fatigue, anorexia, and an unintentional weight loss of 4.1 kg (9 lbs). Past medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and nondistended, with mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and no guarding. There are multiple tender, erythematous nodules on the patient’s shins bilaterally. Laboratory studies show anemia, leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. Stool studies are negative for infectious organisms. Which of the following is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Order CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
Order magnetic resonance imaging with small bowel enterography

questions.solution:
Crohn disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the GI tract (from the mouth to the anus). It typically presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. It is characterized by transmural inflammation and most commonly affects the ileum.  

It can be difficult to differentiate IBD from other diagnoses with similar presentations. Fecal calprotectin is a marker of colon inflammation. Since irritable bowel syndrome does not cause colon inflammation, a positive fecal calprotectin would increase the suspicion for IBD. Negative stool PCR or culture rules out infectious etiologies such as C. difficile, E. coli, Yersinia, and other infections. In patients with new or uncontrolled IBD, serum studies often demonstrate anemia, volume depletion, malnutrition, and elevated inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP.  

If the clinical findings and laboratory workup suggests IBD, the next step is to confirm the diagnosis with ileocolonoscopy with biopsy. In Crohn disease, biopsy samples from affected areas can show the characteristic transmural inflammation and non-caseating granulomas. Patients with suspected Crohn disease can also undergo magnetic resonance enterography (MRE) to evaluate the small bowel. MRE can reveal complications such as strictures, fistulas, and mesenteric fibrofatty proliferation (also called creeping fat).  

Mild-moderate Crohn disease presents with symptoms that minimally affect a patient’s quality of life and without any systemic signs or symptoms or significant weight loss. Moderate-severe Crohn disease presents with significant clinical symptoms (e.g., fever, severe pain, weight loss) and abnormal serum laboratory studies. Severe-fulminant Crohn disease presents with severe malnutrition (e.g. cachexia) or complications such as bowel obstruction or peritonitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform ileocolonoscopy with biopsies   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Order CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast   :
Incorrect: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast may be helpful for evaluating for complications of Crohn disease – such as abscesses, fistulae, and strictures – but is not the best next step in the diagnostic workup of this patient.   
❌ Measure serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA)   :
Incorrect: Serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies levels and fecal calprotectin assay may aid in making the diagnosis of Crohn disease and ruling out other diagnoses, but they are not specific and should not be relied on as diagnostic tests.   
❌ Perform a fecal calprotectin assay   :
Incorrect: Serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies levels and fecal calprotectin assay may aid in making the diagnosis of Crohn disease, but they are not specific and should not be relied on as diagnostic tests.   
❌ Order magnetic resonance imaging with small bowel enterography   :
Incorrect: Magnetic resonance imaging with small bowel enterography (MRE) is useful for identifying areas of involvement in the small bowel and can be part of the diagnostic workup when Crohn disease is found on ileocolonoscopy, but is much less sensitive than colonoscopy with biopsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic due to diarrhea for the past several weeks. There is no associated fatigue, anorexia, or unintentional weight loss. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable only for mild diffuse abdominal tenderness. Stool studies are negative for infectious organisms. Bloodwork shows mild anemia. An ileocolonoscopy is performed, and biopsies of the colon and terminal ileum are obtained. Pathology shows transmural inflammation and non-caseating granulomas isolated to the ileum. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication for treating this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Once the diagnosis of Crohn disease is confirmed, the severity should be determined based on signs and symptoms such as abdominal pain, presence of bloody diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, anemia, presence of complications, and how much Crohn disease impacts the patient’s quality of life. Treatment is based on severity and the location of involvement within the gastrointestinal tract.  The goal of treatment is to use induction therapy to induce a remission. Once remission is achieved with treatment, a colonoscopy extending to the ileum (ileocolonoscopy) should be repeated in 6-12 months.  

Mild-moderate Crohn disease presents with symptoms that minimally affect a patient’s quality of life. Patients typically do not have nausea, vomiting, or fever. Serum laboratory studies do not typically show anemia, dehydration, or malnutrition, and imaging does not show complications. Budesonide is a steroid that is used for induction of remission in patients with mild-moderate Crohn disease with ileocecal involvement, the most common site of involvement in Crohn disease. For patients with predominantly colonic involvement and mild-moderate Crohn disease, an oral 5-aminosalicylate medication should be given (e.g., sulfasalazine).  

Moderate-severe Crohn disease presents with significant clinical symptoms (e.g., fever, severe pain, weight loss) and abnormal serum laboratory studies. This category also includes patients who have failed treatment of mild-moderate Crohn disease. Treatment involves induction therapy with systemic corticosteroids followed by monoclonal antibodies, or immunomodulators (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine).  

Severe-fulminant Crohn disease presents with severe malnutrition (i.e. cachexia) or complications such as bowel obstruction or peritonitis. Treatment also involves induction therapy with systemic corticosteroids followed by monoclonal antibodies or immunomodulators (e.g., methotrexate, azathioprine). These patients are at high risk for requiring surgical interventions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Oral budesonide   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ IV corticosteroids   :
Incorrect: This patient’s Crohn disease would be considered mild given that there are no constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, fatigue). This patient does not meet criteria for hospital admission for IV corticosteroids.   
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is generally reserved for patients with moderate-severe Crohn disease who have failed to respond to other therapies. It is typically used as a second-line or third-line therapy after corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive agents have been tried.   
❌ Ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat infections in the gastrointestinal tract, but is not effective for the treatment of Crohn disease.   
❌ Sulfasalazine:
Incorrect: Sulfasalazine is typically used to treat mild-moderate Crohn disease that is limited to the colon. This patient only has ileocecal involvement without colon involvement.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction presents to his primary care physician’s office for a follow-up visit after an incidental imaging finding on CT angiography showed 75% occlusion of the celiac artery and 70% occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery. He has not experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss. He states he has his usual good appetite. He currently smokes 1 pack per day of cigarettes. His medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metoprolol. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, his abdomen is nontender and without rebound or guarding. Which of the following is appropriate management at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient has significant stenosis of 2 mesenteric vessels, which can lead to acute or chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI). He does not exhibit symptoms of chronic mesenteric ischemia which include postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea, weight loss and food aversion. Some patients with stenosis of mesenteric vessels can be asymptomatic due to collateral blood flow.

In most instances of significant CMI (≥ 70% stenosis of 2 or more mesenteric vessels) with symptoms, treatment is aimed at improving blood flow to the intestines in an effort to reduce symptoms and improve quality of life. Revascularization techniques may include angioplasty and stent placement or bypass graft. However, when stenosis is found incidentally and/or the patient does not have symptoms related to CMI, conservative therapy can be utilized to minimize progression of the disease. This includes antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin), as well as management of potential contributing conditions (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes).  Additionally, smoking cessation counseling should be provided, if relevant. Duplex ultrasound monitoring is also important for tracking disease progression.

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking cessation counseling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rivaroxaban:
Incorrect: Anticoagulation is generally not warranted for asymptomatic mesenteric vessel occlusion.  
❌ Surgical consultation for stent placement:
Incorrect: Revascularization is warranted for symptomatic chronic mesenteric ischemia. However, in asymptomatic or incidental cases of mesenteric vessel occlusion, conservative management is appropriate.  
❌ Surgical consultation for bypass:
Incorrect: Revascularization is warranted for symptomatic chronic mesenteric ischemia. However, in asymptomatic or incidental cases of mesenteric vessel occlusion, conservative management is appropriate.  
❌ Watchful waiting:
Incorrect: While this patient may not have concerning symptoms, it is still important to manage risk factors for the progression of his vascular stenosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to constipation. For the past two months the patient has only been having bowel movements every 5-6 days. The patient’s stool is very firm and difficult to pass, and frequently causes anal pain after defecation. Sometimes there is a small amount of bright red blood on the toilet paper after the patient wipes. The patient’s appetite has been poor lately due to bloating and mild lower quadrant abdominal pain. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient’s abdomen is slightly distended and mildly firm and tender to palpation in the lower quadrants. On the digital rectal exam, there is a firm stool in the rectal vault as well as a 1 cm mucosal tear at the posterior anus. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with decreased frequency of bowel movements and stools that are difficult to pass which are the characteristics of constipation. The patient has pain after defecation and has developed a small anal fissure which can cause small amounts of bright red blood when wiping. In addition, physical exam findings of slightly distended, firm, and tender lower abdominal quadrants, and digital rectal exam with hard stool in the rectal vault and an anal fissure all support the diagnosis of constipation. The next step in management should be reviewing the patient’s medication list as medications are frequently the cause of constipation. If there are no obvious culprit medications, other organic etiologies can be pursued before a diagnosis of functional constipation can be made. Patients should also be asked about fluid intake, diet (especially fiber), physical activity, and habits around bowel movements.
 

Medication-induced constipation is a common cause of constipation. Opioids are the most common medication that can cause opioid-induced constipation. Opioid medications are a frequent cause of constipation in patients with chronic pain or cancer-related pain. Several other medications such as calcium channel blockers (e.g. amlodipine), antidepressants, and agents with anticholinergic properties (e.g., diphenhydramine, oxybutynin) may cause non-opioid-related constipation. If feasible, the culprit medication should be discontinued and swapped out for a different type of medication or even a lower dose of the medication if possible. Lifestyle modifications should be reinforced and other medications (such as osmotic or stimulant laxatives) may need to be added.  

Option Analysis

✅ Review medication list:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform a colonoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient’s small amount of bright red blood can be explained by the difficulty passing stool and the resultant anal fissure. Colonoscopy is not necessary at this point.  
❌ Perform a flexible sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient’s small amount of bright red blood can be explained by the difficulty passing stool and the resultant anal fissure. Colonoscopy is not necessary at this point.  
❌ Recommend twice-daily fiber supplement:
Incorrect: While this may be necessary to help with regulating bowel movements, a medication reconciliation should be performed first, in case the constipation is a medication side effect.  
❌ Prescribe sennosides-docusate:
Incorrect: While this may be necessary to help with regulating bowel movements, a medication reconciliation should first be performed, in case this is a medication side effect.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient states the pain is located near the upper mid-abdomen and that he has never experienced similar pain before. An upper endoscopy is performed which reveals a single, shallow, 1 cm ulcer in the first part of the duodenum. Biopsies do not reveal Helicobacter pylori, and stool testing for H pylori is negative as well. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient was evaluated in the emergency department two weeks ago for a transient ischemic attack, and he was started on a COX-1 and COX-2 inhibitor. This patient’s current presentation is a result of an adverse effect of which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s duodenal ulcer in the setting of a negative Helicobacter pylori test is most likely an adverse effect of aspirin therapy. Aspirin works by irreversibly inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 (via acetylation). At low doses, it predominantly inhibits COX-1; thereby, preventing platelet synthesis of thromboxane A2 and platelet aggregation. Inhibition of COX-1 in the stomach leads to a decrease in the concentration of cytoprotective prostaglandins, increased production of gastric acid, and decreased mucosal bicarbonate production. Together, these effects increase the risk of developing gastritis, gastric/duodenal ulcers or bleeding.  

Chronic aspirin use is associated with acute renal failure, interstitial nephritis and increased bleeding time. Additional side effects include hypersensitivity reactions such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and anaphylactic reactions. People with nasal polyps and asthma are also more prone to experience aspirin hypersensitivity–referred to as aspirin exacerbated respiratory disease.  Aspirin should not be provided to reduce fever in children with underlying viral infections, as it may lead to Reye’s syndrome–a condition characterized by liver damage and progressive encephalopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect:  Warfarin is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor that is used for chronic anticoagulation in patients with underlying atrial fibrillation or transient ischemic attack/stroke. Although it increases the risk of bleeding, it is not associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.
❌ Heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin can be used temporarily for anticoagulation in patients with transient ischemic attack/stroke. This medication is not associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.  
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor which helps decrease inflammation. It does not inhibit COX-1, thereby minimizing gastroduodenal toxicity.  
❌ Colchicine:
Incorrect: Colchicine inhibits microtubule formation by binding to tubulin. It is not indicated in the management of transient ischemic attack/stroke, nor is it associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the primary care office reporting difficulty with bowel movements for three weeks. She has had to strain to evacuate stool and has had two bowel movements in the last week. There has not been blood with bowel movements or a change in stool caliber, although she notes the stools have been hard. She is currently 18 weeks pregnant and medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Medications include a prenatal vitamin with iron. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Abdomen is gravid without tenderness. There is no tenderness on rectal exam, and there are no lesions or masses. Which of the following most accurately characterizes this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient who is taking a vitamin containing iron for her pregnancy has developed symptoms consistent with constipation. Both iron supplements and pregnancy itself can be associated with constipation. Because there is an underlying cause of the constipation, it would be considered secondary constipation.

The first step in evaluating a patient with constipation is to assess for red flag features. Red flags in constipation are features that raise concern for a serious underlying condition (such as malignancy, obstruction, inflammatory bowel disease, or other acute processes) and should lead to further workup rather than an initial trial of empiric therapy. Some important red flags to consider are hematochezia, unintentional weight loss, a family history of colon cancer, acute onset of constipation in an older adult, a change in stool caliber, or identification of a rectal mass. Signs suggesting malignancy should lead to a prompt endoscopic exam with colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy and biopsy of any suspicious lesions.

Secondary constipation can be diagnosed whenever there is an identifiable secondary cause for the condition. Certain medications, including iron supplements, opiates, and antihypertensives, are known causes of constipation. Endocrine and metabolic disorders can also predispose patients to constipation, including diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, and pregnancy. Pregnancy leads to physiologic and anatomic changes in the gastrointestinal tract that increase the likelihood of constipation. Neurological conditions, such as spinal cord injury, Parkinson’s disease, and multiple sclerosis, are additional causes of secondary constipation. Finally, diseases of the colon, including malignancy and inflammatory bowel disease, as well as diseases of the anorectal area, such as anal fissures, proctitis, and strictures, can lead to constipation.

When there are no identifiable secondary causes, it is considered primary constipation, which can be due to an identified intrinsic problem of the stool evacuation process (like slow transit) or no specific underlying cause may be found. When red flags are not present and no underlying secondary cause is identified, it is reasonable to initiate a trial of empiric treatment. Recommended interventions are lifestyle modifications, including increasing physical activity, water intake, and dietary sources of fiber. The addition of over-the-counter fiber supplements and laxatives is also a reasonable first step in treatment. When the constipation resolves with empiric treatment and no specific underlying cause or red flag is found, typically no further workup is needed. However, specific diagnostic testing should be done to further characterize the constipation as normal transit constipation, slow transit constipation, or dyssynergic defecation/outlet constipation when there is inadequate response to initial interventions.   

Option Analysis

❌ Primary constipation:
Incorrect: Primary constipation is considered when there is no secondary cause of constipation like a medical condition or medication. This patient’s constipation is likely secondary to the combination of pregnancy and iron supplementation.  
❌ Functional constipation:
Incorrect: Functional constipation is when all organic and secondary causes of constipation are ruled out. It would not apply in this case where there are identifiable secondary causes (pregnancy and iron supplementation).  
❌ Idiopathic constipation:
Incorrect: Idiopathic constipation would suggest that the cause is not known; however, in this case, both pregnancy and the use of an iron-containing supplement are likely contributing to the constipation.  
✅ Secondary constipation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Irritable bowel syndrome:
Incorrect: Irritable bowel syndrome is characterized by recurrent and frequent abdominal pain associated with defecation, changes in stool frequency, and/or changes in stool form (appearance).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of abdominal pain and alternating episodes of diarrhea and constipation. She says the pain is relieved following defecation. She does not have hematochezia or unintentional weight loss, and there have been no recent changes to her diet. She has no past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals mild diffuse abdominal tenderness on palpation and no rebound tenderness. No abnormalities are seen on perianal and rectal examination. Laboratory studies show a normal CBC and a negative tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTg-IgA). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with six months of episodes of diarrhea alternating with constipation and abdominal pain that is relieved with defecation likely has irritable bowel syndrome. This patient with both chronic diarrhea and constipation can be diagnosed with mixed type IBS or IBS-M.

IBS is a chronic bowel condition with diagnosis requiring patients to have at least three months of symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent abdominal pain that is associated with abnormal bowel movements (e.g. diarrhea, constipation, alternating diarrhea, and constipation). Patients should be questioned about red flag features that may indicate colorectal malignancy, including hematochezia, unintentional weight loss, and family history of colon cancer. If red flag features are present, patients should be further evaluated for an organic cause of the abdominal symptoms. If no alarm features are present, then the diagnosis can be made using the Rome IV Criteria for IBS. Patients meet criteria if they have experienced recurrent abdominal pain at least one day per week in the last three months with two or more of the following: abdominal pain that is related to defecation, a change in the frequency of stool, or a change in the appearance of the stool.

The cause of IBS is unknown but could be related to changes in the normal gut microbiota, autonomic dysfunction, altered motility of the gastrointestinal tract, or psychological factors. IBS can be categorized as diarrhea-predominant (IBS-D), constipation-predominant (IBS-C), or mixed (IBS-M).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Irritable bowel syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis typically presents with chronic diarrhea (+/- blood), colicky abdominal pain, urgency, tenesmus, and incontinence. Elevated levels of fecal calprotectin or lactoferrin can be seen on laboratory findings but may be nonspecific. Patients with severe disease may have anemia.  
❌ Celiac disease:
Incorrect: Celiac disease (gluten-sensitive enteropathy) usually presents with diarrhea with bulky, foul-smelling, floating stools secondary to steatorrhea. Malabsorption due to vitamin deficiencies and its sequelae (e.g. neurological disorders) may also be seen. A positive tissue transglutaminase antibody (tTg-IgA) test is strongly suggestive of Celiac disease.  
❌ Crohn disease:
Incorrect: Crohn disease can present similarly to ulcerative colitis with chronic diarrhea (+/- blood), colicky abdominal pain and urgency. The presence of perianal disease including anal fissures, anorectal abscess, and fistulas is more suggestive of Crohn disease.  
❌ Lactose intolerance:
Incorrect: Lactose intolerance typically presents with abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, nausea, and diarrhea within a few hours following ingestion of lactose-containing products.

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of crampy abdominal pain that has been severe and constant for three hours. She has been under a lot of stress lately since starting her surgery rotation. During the past six months, she has had several episodes of diarrhea occurring during the day after meals. She reports non-radiating mid-abdominal pain, nonbloody diarrhea, and frequent flatulence over the same time frame. The pain is often worse during defecation. She has no family history of colon cancer or other gastrointestinal malignancies. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals mild diffuse abdominal tenderness on palpation without rebound or guarding. No abnormalities are seen on perianal and rectal examination. Laboratory studies show a normal CBC and a negative tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTg-IgA). Which of the following additional findings would be consistent with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Six months of stools consistent with type 6 or 7 on the Bristol Stool Scale

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which is a chronic gastrointestinal condition that presents with chronic recurrent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both) for at least three months duration. IBS can be categorized as diarrhea-predominant (IBS-D), constipation-predominant (IBS-C), or mixed (IBS-M). Based on this patient’s history and clinical presentation, she likely has diarrhea-predominant IBS, and her stools would be consistent with Type 6 or 7 on the Bristol Stool Chart.

When evaluating patients with suspected IBS, red flag features, such as hematochezia, unintentional weight loss, family history of colon cancer, anemia, and the presence of rectal masses, should be ruled out. Also, other conditions that can present with abdominal pain and/or changes in bowel habits (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease, Celiac disease, and thyroid disorders) should be ruled out with appropriate laboratory studies.

Patients should be asked to describe their stools as part of the evaluation for suspected IBS. This can be challenging or embarrassing for some patients. The Bristol Stool Scale can be used to categorize stool from type 1 (solid hard lumps) to type 7 (entirely liquid and watery). IBS-D is typically categorized as type 6 or 7 on the Bristol Stool Scale.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Six months of stools consistent with type 6 or 7 on the Bristol Stool Scale:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated fecal calprotectin:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of fecal calprotectin is associated with chronic gastrointestinal inflammation and may be seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It would not be seen in irritable bowel syndrome where there is no underlying systemic inflammation.  
❌ Abnormal anoscopy:
Incorrect: Anoscopy is used to examine the rectum and anus and is helpful for evaluating perianal disease (e.g. anal strictures and anal fissures) in patients with suspected Crohn disease.  
❌ Abnormal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level  :
Incorrect: TSH levels can be obtained to diagnose thyroid disorders, which can have gastrointestinal manifestations (e.g. constipation, diarrhea). This patient has no other features of thyroid disease.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of diarrhea and low-grade fevers over the past five weeks. The patient has been having 3-4 episodes of bloody diarrhea every day. Abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea have persisted despite eliminating dairy and gluten products from his diet. The diarrhea is preceded by intense crampy abdominal pain that is relieved with bowel movements. The patient has no history of recent travel and only eats food he prepares. In addition, the patient has measured oral temperatures up to 100.4°F at home. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation throughout the abdomen without rebound or guarding. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Rectal examination shows perianal skin tags. Serum transaminases and bilirubin are normal. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation, including several weeks of bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fevers, is suggestive of an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), most likely Crohn disease. Erythema nodosum is a type of panniculitis characterized by tender red nodules, usually found on the anterior aspects of the legs. It is considered an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD and is associated with both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.

When evaluating a patient with fever, a detailed history and physical examination are essential for determining the underlying etiology. The history should include the fever's characteristics; associated symptoms, including chills, cough, or rash; and any recent travel or exposures as these can hint at infectious, inflammatory, or neoplastic causes. Past medical and medication histories are essential to identify predispositions and potential drug-induced fevers. During the physical examination, vital signs and focused assessments of the skin, lymph nodes, joints, and abdomen are vital for pinpointing signs of specific conditions. Findings such as skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, or hepatosplenomegaly can direct clinicians toward further workup to determine the etiology of the fever.   

Option Analysis

❌ Dermatitis herpetiformis:
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease. Although celiac disease and inflammatory bowel disease may present similarly, there are a few key distinctions. The presence of bloody diarrhea and perianal skin tags in this patient indicates Crohn disease. In addition, dermatitis herpetiformis usually resolves when patients with celiac disease completely eliminate gluten; this patient’s symptoms have persisted despite eliminating gluten. 
✅ Erythema nodosum:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Widespread skin excoriations:
Incorrect: Conditions that result in elevated bilirubin can lead to pruritus and subsequent excoriations. Crohn disease is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, which can present with elevated bilirubin, hepatomegaly, and eventually cirrhosis. However, this patient’s bilirubin is noted to be normal; therefore, pruritus and excoriations would not be expected. 
❌ Pain in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration:
Incorrect: Murphy sign, or pain and discomfort in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration when the examiner’s hands palpate below the liver edge, is an indication of acute cholecystitis. This patient’s more subacute presentation of diarrhea and fever and the presence of perianal is more consistent with Crohn disease. 
❌ Hyporeflexia of bilateral lower extremities:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome can present as lower extremity weakness or paralysis, which is often preceded by a respiratory or gastrointestinal viral illness. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease (specifically, Crohn disease with bloody diarrhea, perianal skin tags, and fever).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with 2-weeks of worsening diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fatigue. The patient states that she has had diarrhea intermittently for the past 2 months, but that it has recently worsened. She has had more than six loose, bloody stools per day for the past two weeks. Today she feels light-headed when standing up. She has not taken medication recently or traveled outside the country. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 106/64 mmHg. Mucous membranes are dry. Skin turgor is diminished. There is diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     10.2 g/dL   
 White blood cell count (WBC)     15,000 /µL   
 Platelets     490,000 /µL   
 C-Reactive Protein (CRP)     50 mg/L   
 Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)     65 mm/hr
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute exacerbation of chronic diarrhea, with signs of dehydration, frequent bloody stools, and evidence of systemic inflammation (elevated WBC count, CRP, and ESR). The priority in managing this patient is to address the dehydration and stabilize her hemodynamic status. Administration of intravenous fluids is the best initial step, followed by further workup to determine the underlying cause of the symptoms.        

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, can present with a gradual onset of symptoms such as frequent, small-volume diarrhea (often bloody), tenesmus, abdominal pain, fatigue, and systemic signs of inflammation. Patients may also experience weight loss and extraintestinal manifestations like joint pain, uveitis, or skin lesions. During an acute flare with dehydration, it is critical to stabilize the patient with an ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) assessment. Once stabilized with intravenous fluids, the next steps in evaluation should include bloodwork, stool tests to rule out infection, and imaging studies like computed tomography (CT) scans to assess for complications (e.g., abscess, fistula). A colonoscopy with biopsy is typically performed once the patient is stable to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While corticosteroids may be appropriate for managing an inflammatory bowel disease flare, they should not be administered before addressing the patient's acute dehydration and hemodynamic instability and then ruling out infection.   
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are not indicated in the absence of signs of bacterial infection, and the most immediate concern for this patient is dehydration, which must be addressed first. 
✅ Intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Colonoscopy :
Incorrect: Although a colonoscopy may be needed for further evaluation, it is not a priority. The patient must first be stabilized with intravenous fluids before undergoing invasive diagnostic procedures. 
❌ Oral rehydration and reassurance:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration is preferred in stable patients with mild or moderate dehydration; this patient has lightheadedness, tachycardia, and low blood pressure related to her dehydration, making intravenous fluids a better choice. This patient requires further workup of her condition and oral rehydration and reassurance alone is not sufficient treatment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with a history of frequent bloody loose stools and generalized abdominal pain that started 3 months ago and has progressively worsened. The patient has also been feeling fatigued and has had an unintentional weight loss of 6.6 lbs (3 kg) in the past 3 months. He has no past medical history and is not currently taking any medications. He has a sedentary lifestyle and has no history of recent travel. He is sexually active with his partner and uses condoms consistently. BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is significant for mild generalized abdominal tenderness on palpation, bright red blood on digital rectal exam, and a painful ulcer with a purulent base and violaceous border on the right abdomen. Laboratory findings are significant for a hemoglobin of 10.8 g/dL, a mild elevation in CRP, and a positive fecal occult blood test. Which of the following will most likely establish the diagnosis of this patient’s underlying disease?
questions.solution:
This patient has a 3-month history of frequent bloody loose stools, generalized abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Physical examination shows generalized abdominal tenderness, blood in the rectum, and a painful ulcer with a purulent base and violaceous border consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum. Laboratory evaluation shows mild anemia, mild elevation in CRP, and a positive FOBT. These findings are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).    

Diagnosis of UC is made in patients with chronic diarrhea with a colonoscopy with biopsies, which may reveal erythema, a decreased or absent vascular pattern, friability, and ulcerations in a continuous pattern starting from the rectum (proctitis), which is always involved, and progressing to beyond the splenic flexure (extensive colitis). Colonoscopy should also rule out other causes. Findings on histopathological examination consistent with ulcerative colitis include mucosal and submucosal chronic inflammation, erosion/ulceration, and crypt abscesses.    

Once the diagnosis of UC has been made, severity should be assessed as it dictates management. Severity is determined based on signs and symptoms, laboratory findings, and findings on colonoscopy. Ulcerative colitis can be categorized into 3 classifications based on severity: mild-to-moderate UC, moderate-severe UC, and acute severe UC.  

●  Patients with mild-to-moderate UC have 0-3 stools per day with intermittent blood, mild crampy abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Patients typically do not have weight loss, signs of systemic toxicity, or anemia. Inflammatory markers are typically normal.  
●  Patients with moderate-to-severe UC have 4 to 6 loose bloody stools per day, mild-moderate crampy abdominal pain, and tenesmus. They typically do not present with weight loss or signs of systemic toxicity. Laboratory studies may reveal mild anemia and slightly elevated inflammatory markers.  
●  Patients with acute severe UC have more than 6 loose bloody stools per day, severe crampy abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss, evidence of systemic toxicity, severe anemia that may require transfusion, and elevated inflammatory markers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy with biopsy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stool ova and parasite analysis  :
Incorrect: Stool ova and parasite analysis should be performed in patients presenting with diarrhea for more than four weeks, especially if there is recent travel. Entamoeba histolytica colitis can present with chronic symptoms of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea in a patient with a travel to endemic areas. In this patient the absence of travel history and the presence of pyoderma gangrenosum on skin examination makes the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis more likely.  
❌ Fecal calprotectin levels  :
Incorrect: Fecal calprotectin is a nonspecific marker of colon inflammation; it can be useful in distinguishing between inflammatory and non-inflammatory causes of chronic diarrhea. However, it is not a diagnostic test for ulcerative colitis as the diagnosis of suspected ulcerative colitis (UC) in a patient with a positive fecal calprotectin should be confirmed by a colonoscopy with biopsies.  
❌ Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy  :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy is important for the diagnosis of celiac disease. Although it can present with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, the diarrhea is usually non-bloody, bulky, and foul-smelling. The presence of blood in the stools and the positive FOBT makes this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Biopsy of the skin ulcer  :
Incorrect: Biopsy of the skin ulcer would be important for the definitive diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum which can be seen with a number of diseases. However, given the patient’s history of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea, it is likely that he has pyoderma gangrenosum secondary to underlying ulcerative colitis which should be diagnosed with colonoscopy with biopsies.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with Crohn disease presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and abdominal pain. Several days ago, the patient started having 5-6 episodes of diarrhea and cramping abdominal pain. Over the past 24 hours, the patient has not had any diarrhea and has been unable to pass flatulence. Worsening nausea and vomiting has also developed over this time period. Temperature is 38.1 ºC (100.6 °F), heart rate is 115/min, blood pressure is 94/62 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Physical exam reveals a soft, distended abdomen that is tender to palpation. High-pitched, tinkling bowel sounds are present on auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous access and administration of fluids
CT abdomen and pelvis for evaluation of abdominal abscess
Abdominal radiograph for evaluation of small bowel obstruction

questions.solution:
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a condition characterized by chronic gastrointestinal tract inflammation that can be subdivided into Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis (UC). Crohn disease can affect any part of the GI tract (from the mouth to the anus) and is characterized by transmural skip lesions which can lead to abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and fever. It can be categorized as mild to moderate, moderate to severe, or severe. Management is based on the severity of disease. When evaluating a patient with suspected Crohn disease, physicians should first perform an ABCrohn diseaseE assessment (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) to determine if the patient is stable or unstable.  

Patients with severe Crohn disease might present with signs of shock like tachycardia and refractory hypotension. Because of the high mortality risk in these individuals, it is essential to hospitalize them, obtain intravenous access, and start them on IV fluids. Once they are stable, look for the cause of their instability, such as small bowel obstruction or sepsis from an abscess.  

Patients with Crohn disease who develop an acute small bowel obstruction (SBO) typically have symptoms of nausea, vomiting, cramping, abdominal pain, and inability to pass flatus or stool (this is called obstipation). SBO may result from a stricture causing mechanical obstruction. Medical management with intravenous hydration, bowel rest, and nasogastric suction is often successful, with a response seen within 24 to 48 hours. Patients who do not respond to medical management may require parenteral nutrition and surgical interventions.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous access and administration of fluids   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Immediate surgical consultation   :
Incorrect: While this patient may eventually require a surgical consultation for evaluation and management of small bowel obstruction, he should first be stabilized. For unstable patients (i.e. hypotensive and tachycardic) intravenous access should be obtained and patients should be started on IV fluids. Once they are stable, further work-up to determine the cause of their instability should be pursued.   
❌ CT abdomen and pelvis for evaluation of abdominal abscess   :
Incorrect: While this patient may eventually require further imaging to characterize the abdominal pain and extent and severity of the Crohn disease, he should first be stabilized. For unstable patients (e.g., hypotensive and tachycardic) intravenous access should be obtained and patients should be started on IV fluids. Once they are stable, further work-up to determine the cause of their instability should be pursued.   
❌ Abdominal radiograph for evaluation of small bowel obstruction   :
Incorrect: While this patient may eventually require further imaging to characterize the abdominal pain and investigate the signs and symptoms of SBO, he should first be stabilized. For unstable patients (e.g., hypotensive and tachycardic) intravenous access should be obtained and patients should be started on IV fluids. Once they are stable, further work-up to determine the cause of their instability should be pursued.   
❌ Nasogastric decompression   :
Incorrect: While this patient may eventually require further interventions to manage a likely small bowel obstruction (e.g., distended abdomen, high-pitched tinkling sounds) including nasogastric decompression with an NG tube and suction, he should first be stabilized. For unstable patients (e.g., hypotensive and tachycardic), intravenous access should be obtained and patients should be started on IV fluids. Once they are stable, further work-up to determine the cause of their instability should be pursued.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to her primary care physician’s office for abdominal pain for the past few months. She describes the pain as crampy. It usually occurs about 30–40 minutes after eating a meal. The pain lasts about an hour. Due to this, she has been avoiding some meals and has lost about 10 lbs. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination there is mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. An epigastric bruit is heard. CT angiography is ordered. Which of the following findings would be expected on imaging?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of crampy, postprandial abdominal pain, food aversion, and weight loss are concerning for chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI). CMI occurs when there is decreased blood flow within the mesenteric vasculature, often due to narrowing of the blood vessels by atherosclerotic plaques.

Diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging (CT or MR angiography) showing stenosis of 2 or more major mesenteric vessels (e.g., celiac, superior mesenteric, or inferior mesenteric artery).  Duplex ultrasonography is typically used as a screening test, while CT angiography is the preferred definitive diagnostic test. Additionally, imaging can reveal the degree of stenosis, which will help guide management decisions.

Keep in mind, the symptoms of abdominal pain and weight loss often lead to esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy being performed as a way to rule out GI malignancies. In patients with these symptoms and a negative endoscopic evaluation, consider CMI in the differential diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Thrombosis of the portal vein:
Incorrect: Portal vein thrombosis typically occurs in the setting of cirrhosis or other prothrombotic diseases and can be asymptomatic or associated with acute abdominal pain. This patient’s history, symptoms, and physical exam findings are more suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
❌ Renal infarct:
Incorrect: Renal infarction is typically associated with acute flank pain and nausea. This patient’s history, symptoms, and physical exam findings are more consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
❌ Splenic infarct:
Incorrect: Splenic infarction typically presents with acute left upper quadrant pain in the setting of hypercoagulable or embolic disease (e.g., atrial fibrillation). This patient’s symptoms, history, and physical exam findings are more consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
✅ Stenosis of the mesenteric arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm:
Incorrect: Most individuals with an abdominal aortic aneurysm are asymptomatic and the aneurysm is detected incidentally; though abdominal, flank, or back pain can occur. However, food aversion and weight loss are more concerning for chronic mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is seen in the primary care clinic due to persistent constipation. The patient has severe lumbar spinal stenosis and has taken oxycodone 10 mg every four hours for the past month. The dose has been titrated up over time, and the patient feels relief of pain at the current dose. The patient otherwise has no medical history and takes no other medications. The patient’s last bowel movement was six days ago and bowel movements have been very firm and difficult to pass. On physical examination, the patient has abdominal distension in both lower quadrants with minimal left lower quadrant tenderness to palpation. Counseling on fluid intake, increased physical activity, and a high-fiber diet is provided. The patient is started on a combination of senna and polyethylene glycol without resolution of symptoms. Which of the following medications should be given at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient has been using opioids (oxycodone) for the past month and has developed opioid-induced constipation (OIC). Lifestyle changes and a combination of stimulant and osmotic laxatives have not relieved this patient’s constipation. Therefore, a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist (PAMORA) – such as naloxegol or methylnaltrexone should be started.

Constipation refers to decreased stool frequency or significant difficulty passing stool. Medications are a common cause of constipation. Opioids are the most common medication to cause this, but several other medications such as calcium channel blockers (e.g. amlodipine), antidepressants and agents with anticholinergic properties (e.g., diphenhydramine, oxybutynin) may also be the cause. If feasible, the culprit medication should be discontinued and swapped out for something else (e.g. hydrocodone in this case), or the dose should be decreased if possible. Lifestyle modifications are very important and include adjusting stooling habits (e.g. defecating immediately upon getting an urge), increasing fluid and fiber intake, and increasing physical activity.
 

If OIC persists despite medication adjustments and lifestyle changes then medications can be added including osmotic laxatives (e.g. polyethylene glycol) and stimulant laxatives (e.g. sennosides). If constipation persists despite all these measures, then a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist – such as naloxegol or methylnaltrexone – should be added. These inhibit opioid effects in the intestines without causing significant reversal of opioid CNS effects.  

Option Analysis

✅ Methylnaltrexone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Naltrexone:
Incorrect: This medication reverses the CNS effects of opioids. This could cause significant withdrawal side effects and the return of pain in this patient without effectively treating the opioid-induced constipation.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: This medication reverses the CNS effects of opioids. This could cause significant opioid withdrawal side effects and the return of pain in this patient without effectively treating the opioid-induced constipation.  
❌ Docusate:
Incorrect: Docusate is a stool softener and is weakly effective for constipation. It is unlikely to provide significant benefit for severe constipation and other agents should be used instead.  
❌ Diphenoxylate-atropine:
Incorrect: This medication is an anti-diarrheal (like loperamide) and can worsen constipation. This medication is not appropriate for this patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain. His symptoms started four months ago. He has not seen any blood in his stool. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. He follows a balanced diet but has stopped consuming milk as it exacerbates the symptoms. He has not experienced any changes in weight or appetite. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following disease processes most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Presence of unabsorbed solutes in the intestines
Secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen
Inflammation of the intestinal wall with granuloma formation
Bacterial invasion of the intestinal wall with inflammatory cell infiltration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with crampy abdominal pain and intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is exacerbated by consuming lactose containing foods. These findings are suggestive of lactose intolerance, which is a type of osmotic diarrhea. Affected patients lack the enzyme lactase. As a result, lactose cannot be broken down and remains in the intestinal lumen, where it is osmotically active and prevents water absorption by the intestines.

Osmotic diarrhea occurs due to the presence of unabsorbed solutes (e.g. lactose) in the intestinal lumen. These unabsorbed solutes exert an osmotic power, trapping water in the lumen as well as drawing water into the lumen. Osmotic diarrhea is watery, non-bloody, and typically resolves when the causative substance (e.g., food, medication) is discontinued.

Another type of diarrhea is secretory diarrhea, which can occur in certain infections (e.g. Vibrio cholera) and some gastrointestinal disorders (e.g. VIPoma). It results from excessive secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen, which exerts an osmotic effect and sucks fluid from the surrounding tissues into the intestinal lumen. Secretory diarrhea is also watery, and non-bloody, but unlike osmotic diarrhea, persists even with decreased oral intake.

Moreover, there is inflammatory (exudative) diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is typically seen in patients with certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease) or bacterial (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni) invasion of the intestinal wall. These conditions lead to an inflammatory process that damages the intestinal epithelium. The diarrhea is usually purulent, bloody, and persists during fasting. Systemic symptoms such as fever, tachycardia, and weight loss may also be seen.

Finally, diarrhea can occur due to increased gastrointestinal motility, which causes water and nutrients to reach the colon too fast without adequate time for proper digestion and absorption. Potential etiologies include irritable bowel syndrome and hyperthyroidism.  

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of unabsorbed solutes in the intestines:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: Secretory diarrhea is due to the secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen. Examples of secretory diarrhea include infections (e.g. Vibrio cholera) as well as other conditions such as VIPoma. In contrast, this patient has intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is associated with milk ingestion, which is more suggestive of lactose intolerance.  
❌ Inflammation of the intestinal wall with granuloma formation:
Incorrect: Crohn disease is characterized by intestinal wall inflammation and granuloma formation. It is associated with inflammatory diarrhea that is often purulent and bloody. In contrast, this patient has intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is associated with milk ingestion, which is more suggestive of lactose intolerance.  
❌ Bacterial invasion of the intestinal wall with inflammatory cell infiltration:
Incorrect: Certain bacteria (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, Shigella species) invade and destroy the epithelial lining of the intestinal wall and induce an inflammatory response. Bacterial infection typically presents acutely with bloody diarrhea and systemic manifestations (e.g. fever, chills). In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are suggestive of another underlying etiology.  
❌ Deficiency in pancreatic digestive enzymes:
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis and resulting pancreatic enzyme insufficiency leads to fat malabsorption and steatorrhea. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with lactose intolerance, which is due to a deficiency of the brush border enzyme lactase.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic due to 4 weeks of fatigue and malaise. The patient was diagnosed with Crohn disease 1 year ago and was initially treated with long-term glucocorticoids. Two months ago, the patient was weaned off glucocorticoids and switched to azathioprine. Temperature is 37.1 ºC (98.8 ºF), pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 122/78 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears pale, with scattered bruises over the body. Complete blood count is shown below. Decreased activity of which of the following enzymes could explain this patient's condition?

 Complete blood count (CBC)
 Hemoglobin  8.3 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  25% 
 MCV  85 fl 
 Reticulocyte count  1% 
 Leukocyte count  500/mm3 
 Platelet count  30,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe pancytopenia two months after starting azathioprine for Crohn disease. Severe or recurrent pancytopenia in patients taking azathioprine should raise the suspicion of decreased activity of thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT), an enzyme that is responsible for the degradation of the active metabolites of azathioprine.  

Azathioprine is a prodrug that gets converted to its active metabolite 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) by the action of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). 6-MP then inhibits purine synthesis, suppressing DNA and RNA synthesis and halting cellular division. These effects are most noted in actively dividing cells, including immune cells. In this way, azathioprine inhibits the proliferation of immune cells and suppresses the immune system. Azathioprine is used in autoimmune disorders (e.g., autoimmune hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease), and can also be used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients. The major side effects of azathioprine are bone marrow suppression and pancreatitis.  

Due to genetic polymorphism, some people have lower or absent activity of TPMT. Such people are more likely to develop bone marrow suppression due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites of 6-MP and azathioprine. Additionally, patients taking xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. allopurinol) concurrently with azathioprine or 6-MP are at increased risk of toxicity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thiopurine methyltransferase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: HGPRT is the enzyme responsible for converting azathioprine to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits purine synthesis. Decreased activity of HGPRT would result in decreased activity of the azathioprine and thus decreased side effects.
❌ Cytochrome p450:
Incorrect: Cytochrome p450 (CYP-450) is a group of hepatic enzymes that are responsible for the metabolism of numerous drugs and toxins. Polymorphism is seen in the cytochrome P450 system, which accounts for different activity levels in the population. Azathioprine is not metabolized by cytochrome p450
❌ Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of 5-fluorouracil. Decreased activity of this enzyme results in increased toxicity in patients taking 5-FU. However, it is not involved in azathioprine metabolism.
❌ Aldehyde dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Aldehyde dehydrogenase is responsible for breaking down acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate product of ethanol metabolism. Deficiency in this enzyme results in the accumulation of acetaldehyde after alcohol consumption, causing symptoms like facial flushing, headache, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for nausea, abdominal pain, and non-bloody vomiting for the past 24 hours. These symptoms are associated with decreased appetite. The patient is not sexually active. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation without guarding or rebound tenderness. CT of the abdomen shows dilated loops of the small bowel. A nasogastric tube is placed. Further history shows this patient has been taking excessive amounts of laxatives in an effort to lose weight. Which class of laxatives did this patient most likely misuse?
questions.solution:
Bulk-forming laxatives such as methylcellulose, polycarbophil, and psyllium are hydrophilic colloids derived from indigestible fruit and vegetable matter. They are commonly used over the counter to aid in constipation prevention or relief. These laxatives swell in the digestive tract as they absorb water. The distention of the intestinal walls caused by their swelling creates reflexive peristalsis. Bulk-forming laxatives require a significant amount of water in order to function. If taken without sufficient quantities of water, the bulk-forming laxative can become impacted, creating small bowel obstruction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Osmotic laxatives:
Incorrect:  Osmotic laxatives (magnesium salts, sodium sulfate, sorbitol), lactulose, and polyethylene glycol each function to draw water into the bowel lumen to promote large bowel motility. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
❌ Stimulant laxatives:
Incorrect: Stimulant laxatives such as senna and bisacodyl promote large bowel motility by direct inflammation of the bowel mucosa. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
✅ Bulk forming agents:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chloride channel activators:
Incorrect: Chloride channel activators such as lubiprostone cause a hyperosmotic effect, drawing water into the bowel lumen and thus promoting bowel motility. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
❌ Opioid antagonists:
Incorrect:  Opioid antagonists such as alvimopan and methylnaltrexone are used for opioid-induced constipation (OIC). They block gastrointestinal mu-opioid receptors, which allows propagation of downstream acetylcholine signaling in cases of OIC.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the hospital for routine colonoscopy screening. The patient’s first screening colonoscopy 10 years ago was normal without any polyps. The patient has chronic constipation and routinely takes senna to help promote bowel movements. Prior to the colonoscopy, vital signs are unremarkable.  Physical exam does not show any abdominal distention or tenderness to palpation. During colonoscopy, dark pigmented spots are visualized in multiple locations throughout the colon. Which of the following most likely caused these findings on this patient’s colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
The dark spots throughout this patient’s colon are referred to as “melanosis coli.” Melanosis coli is caused by stimulant laxatives such as senna and bisacodyl. As the metabolic breakdown products of these laxatives pass through the colon, they become active and cause cell death and apoptosis in the lining of the colon, causing lipofuscin deposition (not melanin as the name might imply) and eventually dark pigmentation of the colon. Melanosis coli is not associated with an increased risk of colon cancer and resolves with the discontinuation of laxatives.

Stimulant laxatives act by causing direct inflammation of the colon, which in turn causes the colon to reflexively undergo peristalsis. Stimulant laxatives are meant to be used as short-term therapies for constipation, and should not usually be used on a chronic basis. Dietary alterations, patient education, and regular exercise are key first steps for the treatment of constipation, followed by bulking agents such as psyllium, if indicated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metastatic adenocarcinoma to the colon:
Incorrect: Metastatic adenocarcinoma to the colon would likely present with multiple masses visible on imaging and/or on colonoscopy. The findings on this patient’s colonoscopy of dark pigmented spots are not suggestive of any underlying masses. Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer may describe weight loss, fatigue, pencil-thin stools, hematochezia, or others.  
❌ Previous polypectomy:
Incorrect:  When found on colonoscopy, polyps are typically resected and harvested using an endoscopic snare for pathologic analysis in order to assess risk for possible malignancy. Minor bleeding may occur during cold or hot snaring. The finding in this patient’s colonoscopy of dark pigmented mucosa would not likely be from previous polyp resection sites from 10 years ago. More importantly, the patient’s previous colonoscopy is reported as normal.  
❌ Mucosal artifact from repeated colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A well-executed colonoscopy has virtually no chance of chronically irritating the bowel mucosa. Submucosal dissection and perforation are the most common adverse events associated with colonoscopy and carry approximately a 7% and 1% risk, respectively. These would not cause dark pigmented spots in the colon.  
✅ Medication effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis often has profound and easily recognizable findings on colonoscopy including edema, erythema, backwash ileitis, erosions, ulcerations, and loss of the typical vascular pattern. The dark mucosal pigmentation described in this patient’s colonoscopy is not indicative of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with 3-months of chronic diarrhea, characterized by frequent, watery stools that decrease in volume when she fasts. She has not had abdominal pain, blood in the stool, or significant weight loss. She has no recent travel history, new medication, or dietary changes. Her diet consists mostly of whole foods, including grains, vegetables, and low-fat protein. She works at a nightclub as a server. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with normal bowel sounds. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     13.5 g/dL    
 White blood cell (WBC) count     7,500 /µL    
 Platelets     250,000 /µL    
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     2 mg/L    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     15 mm/hr    
 Sodium     140 mEq/L    
 Potassium     4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride     105 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     23 mEq/L    
 Tissue transglutaminase IgA antibodies     Negative    
 Stool Studies    
 Fecal calprotectin     40 µg/g (normal range <50 µg/g)    
 Stool sodium     40 mEq/L    
 Stool potassium     10 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The patient's chronic diarrhea with watery stools that decrease in volume with fasting, combined with an elevated stool osmotic gap (>75 mOsm/kg), is consistent with osmotic diarrhea. Osmotic diarrhea occurs when non-absorbable substances in the bowel lumen cause water retention. The most likely diagnosis in this context is surreptitious use of laxatives, particularly osmotic laxatives like polyethylene glycol or lactulose. This condition often presents without significant systemic inflammation, as indicated by normal CRP and ESR levels. The fecal osmotic gap is calculated as follows: 290 – (2 × [stool sodium + stool potassium]). In this patient, the calculated osmotic gap would be 290 – (2 × [40 + 10]) = 190, consistent with osmotic diarrhea. Patients with osmotic diarrhea have a daily stool volume of less than 200 milliliters.






Option Analysis

❌ Carcinoid syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Carcinoid syndrome typically present with flushing, wheezing, and diarrhea due to serotonin secretion, which does not match this patient's presentation. Furthermore, carcinoid syndrome causes secretory diarrhea, which will present with a stool osmotic gap of less than 50 mOsm/kg that does not change with fasting. This patient’s stool osmotic gap is 190, suggestive of osmotic diarrhea, which can be caused by laxative use.  
❌ Crohn disease:
Incorrect:  Patients with Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn disease, typically presents with diarrhea accompanied by abdominal pain, bloody stools, or extraintestinal symptoms and findings of an elevated fecal calprotectin. This patient’s symptoms and normal fecal calprotectin level are not suggestive of IBD. Osmotic diarrhea from laxative use is more likely. 
✅ Laxative use:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Irritable bowel syndrome:
Incorrect: IBS can cause chronic diarrhea, but patients usually present with associated abdominal pain without a high stool osmotic gap. 
❌ Celiac disease :
Incorrect: Celiac disease may present with malabsorption, weight loss, and nutritional deficiencies, along with positive serological markers, none of which are noted in this patient's history or laboratory results.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department due to a three day history of severe diffuse abdominal pain and six episodes of bloody diarrhea daily. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 98/76 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% of room air. The patient appears ill and dehydrated. Abdominal examination is notable for diffuse abdominal tenderness on palpation without guarding, rebound, or rigidity. Digital rectal exam is significant for bright red blood. Laboratory results are significant for a hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL, thrombocytosis, and an elevated CRP. Stool studies are sent for infectious etiologies including C. difficile. Abdominal x-ray is significant for colonic wall thickening and loss of haustrations. There is no colonic dilatation seen on imaging. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV fluids, IV antibiotics, IV glucocorticoids, and transfuse-packed red blood cells
Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent colectomy
Administer IV fluids and refer for an urgent colonoscopy
Administer high-dose oral glucocorticoids and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks
Administer 5-aminosalicylic acid enema and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks.

questions.solution:
This patient has a three day history of severe diffuse abdominal pain and six episodes of loose bloody stools daily, current presentation of shock (e.g., tachycardia, and hypotension), along with physical examination significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness and laboratory findings significant for anemia and elevated markers of inflammation (elevated CRP, thrombocytosis). Together, these findings suggest an episode of acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC) complicated by hemodynamic instability and hypovolemic shock due to blood loss.    

Acute severe UC is a potentially life-threatening condition as it can be complicated by bowel perforation, toxic megacolon, or severe refractory hemorrhage unresponsive to treatment.
