The initial management of a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected severe acute UC consists of stabilization with IV fluids and possible blood products in the case of hypovolemic shock due to hemorrhage, initiation of IV antibiotics in the presence of fever and systemic toxicity, and administration of IV glucocorticoids.    

Emergency surgery would be indicated in the case of acute severe UC complicated by toxic megacolon evidenced by the presence of colonic dilation on abdominal imaging, perforation evidenced by pneumoperitoneum on abdominal imaging, and massive refractory rectal bleeding unresponsive to resuscitation. Urgent surgery would be indicated in the case of acute severe UC unresponsive to medical treatment.    

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV fluids, IV antibiotics, IV glucocorticoids, and transfuse-packed red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent colectomy  :
Incorrect: Toxic megacolon is a complication of a severe flare of ulcerative colitis, characterized by acute dilation of the colon and signs of systemic toxicity such as fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status. It can be diagnosed in the appropriate clinical situation when the colon is dilated to a diameter of more than 6 cm on imaging studies. This patient does not have colonic dilatation on radiography.  
❌ Administer IV fluids and refer for an urgent colonoscopy  :
Incorrect: Although IV fluids are essential for managing hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC), colonoscopy is contraindicated due to the increased risk of perforation.  
❌ Administer high-dose oral glucocorticoids and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks  :
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically unstable with likely acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC), and therefore, discharging the patient would be inappropriate.  
❌ Administer 5-aminosalicylic acid enema and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks.  :
Incorrect:  This patient is hemodynamically unstable with likely acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC), and therefore, discharging the patient would be inappropriate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 2-month history of bloody diarrhea, LLQ abdominal pain, and fecal urgency. She has no past medical history and is currently not taking any medications. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. Family history is notable for a parent diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome. Vitals are within normal range. Physical examination is significant for mild left lower quadrant abdominal tenderness on palpation without rebound or guarding. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL. Fecal occult blood test is positive. Stool studies are negative for infectious etiologies. Fecal calprotectin is positive. Which of the following additional physical exam findings would most likely be present?
questions.solution:
This patient has a 2-month history of bloody diarrhea, LLQ abdominal pain, and fecal urgency. These symptoms are typical of ulcerative colitis. Laboratory evaluation shows mild anemia, a positive fecal occult blood test (FOBT), and a positive fecal calprotectin. These findings are most concerning for ulcerative colitis, which is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon, causing continuous ulcerations of the mucosa and submucosa. It has a bimodal pattern of incidence according to age with two peaks: the first between the ages of 15 and 30, and the second between the ages of 50 and 70.   

History typically reveals bloody diarrhea, diffuse or periumbilical crampy abdominal pain, tenesmus, and fecal urgency. Some patients may report extraintestinal symptoms, like eye pain and redness, joint pain and swelling, and rashes. Physical examination typically reveals abdominal tenderness to palpation. Rectal exam might reveal bright red blood and discomfort on palpation. Additionally, there might be extra-intestinal findings involving the eyes (e.g., uveitis, episcleritis), the skin (e.g., erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), and the hepatobiliary system (e.g., jaundice due to primary sclerosing cholangitis).  

Erythema nodosum is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction that causes acute panniculitis and manifests as raised, tender, erythematous nodules or plaques on the lower extremities, most commonly on the shins. It is associated with inflammatory bowel disease, infections (e.g., Streptococcus, Tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis), sarcoidosis, and medications (e.g., antibiotics, oral contraceptives). It is the most common dermatologic manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, and its appearance coincides with intestinal activity.  


Option Analysis

✅ Erythema nodosum  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perianal skin tags  :
Incorrect:  Perianal skin tags, which appear as pedunculated lesions on a narrow stalk in the anal region, can be found in Crohn disease. Although Crohn disease can present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and positive fecal calprotectin, gross blood may or may not be seen in the stool. Patients with Crohn disease typically have right sided abdominal pain, fatigue, and diarrhea that may or may not be bloody as their main symptoms.  
❌ Ecthyma gangrenosum  :
Incorrect:  Ecthyma gangrenosum is a severe life-threatening, rapidly progressive painless gangrenous ulcer that may present in immunocompromised patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia/sepsis. It may be confused with pyoderma gangrenosum, which is a dermatologic manifestation of ulcerative colitis.    
❌ Swan neck deformity  :
Incorrect:  Swan neck deformity, which is characterized by the hyperextension of PIP joints and flexion of DIP joints of the hands, is a finding seen in rheumatoid arthritis. Inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis/arthropathy typically involves the large joints or the spine and hips when ankylosing spondylitis is present.  
❌ Dermatitis herpetiformis  :
Incorrect:  Dermatitis herpetiformis, which is characterized by the presence of intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, and buttocks, is a manifestation of gluten sensitivity and celiac disease. It is not associated with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of diarrhea and low-grade fevers over the past several weeks. The patient has been having 3-4 episodes of bloody diarrhea almost every day. Abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea have persisted despite eliminating dairy and gluten products from his diet. The diarrhea is preceded by intense cramping abdominal pain that is relieved with bowel movements. In addition, the patient has measured oral temperatures up to 100.4°F at home. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation throughout the abdomen. Rectal examination shows perianal skin tags. Serum transaminases and bilirubin are normal. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a condition characterized by chronic gastrointestinal tract inflammation that can be subdivided into Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis (UC). Crohn disease can affect any part of the GI tract (from the mouth to the anus) and is characterized by transmural skip lesions which can lead to abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and fever.  

History in patients with Crohn disease typically demonstrates postprandial abdominal pain – usually in the right lower quadrant – and often non-bloody diarrhea. However, if the disease is in the colon, the patient might report bloody diarrhea. Additionally, many patients report fatigue, weight loss, and fever. History and physical exam should look for extraintestinal manifestations such as joint pain, eye pain and redness, and skin findings such as erythematous, raised, tender lesions on the lower extremities consistent with erythema nodosum. Painful ulcerations known as pyoderma gangrenosum can also be seen in patients with inflammatory bowel disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema nodosum   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dermatitis herpetiformis   :
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease. Although celiac disease and inflammatory bowel disease may present similarly, there are a few key distinctions in this patient: bloody diarrhea and perianal skin tags are associated with Crohn disease and not Celiac. In addition, dermatitis herpetiformis usually resolves when patients with celiac disease completely eliminate gluten; this patient’s symptoms have persisted despite eliminating gluten.   
❌ Widespread skin excoriations   :
Incorrect: Conditions that result in elevated bilirubin can lead to pruritus and subsequent excoriations. Crohn disease is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, which can present with elevated bilirubin, hepatomegaly, and eventually cirrhosis. However, this patient’s bilirubin is normal, and therefore pruritus and excoriations would not be expected.   
❌ Murphy sign   :
Incorrect: Murphy sign, or pain and discomfort in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration when the examiner’s hands palpate below the liver edge, is an indication of acute cholecystitis. This patient’s diarrhea, fever, and perianal skin tags are more consistent with Crohn disease.
❌ Hyporeflexia of bilateral lower extremities   :
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome can present as lower extremity weakness or paralysis which is often preceded by a respiratory or gastrointestinal viral illness. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease – specifically, Crohn disease with bloody diarrhea, perianal skin tags, and fever.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for routine follow-up. Her medical history includes COPD, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. She currently smokes ½ pack per day. She has had long-standing crampy, postprandial abdominal pain and occasional nausea. These episodes typically last about 30 minutes, and she has not noticed any worsening of her symptoms. On physical examination, her abdomen is nontender and nondistended. A bruit is noted on auscultation of the epigastric region. Which of the following additional symptoms would be consistent with her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s crampy, postprandial abdominal pain, and epigastric bruit on exam are consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI). In addition, she has multiple risk factors for CMI, including her age, smoking history, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes.

CMI occurs when there is decreased blood flow within the mesenteric vasculature, often due to narrowing of the blood vessels by atherosclerotic plaques. Symptoms classically occur after meals, since the intestines have a higher demand for perfusion during this period. These symptoms may include crampy abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea. This may lead patients to fear meals (food aversion) in anticipation of discomfort, which may eventually result in weight loss.  

Option Analysis

❌ Jaundice:
Incorrect: Jaundice is often caused by conditions affecting the liver, such as hepatitis. However, this patient’s symptoms and history are more consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
✅ Food aversion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal pain relieved with defecation:
Incorrect: Pain that is relieved by defecation is more commonly associated with irritable bowel syndrome. This patient’s history and symptoms are more consistent with chronic mesenteric ischemia.  
❌ Hematemesis:
Incorrect: Hematemesis is not typically associated with chronic mesenteric ischemia, and would be more concerning for stomach or esophageal pathology, such as peptic ulcer disease or varices.  
❌ Increased appetite:
Incorrect: Patients with chronic mesenteric ischemia are more likely to experience food aversion than an increased appetite.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is seen in the primary care clinic for an annual visit. The patient had a tooth removed four days ago due to infection and has been on amoxicillin-clavulanate since then. The patient has also been prescribed 5 mg tablets of hydrocodone-acetaminophen and has taken two doses per day for the past two days. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, mild gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, and iron deficiency anemia secondary to heavy periods. Current medications include metformin, ferrous sulfate, and as-needed magnesium hydroxide for reflux symptoms. The patient otherwise feels well. She mentions that she has not had a bowel movement in six days which is abnormal for her. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s decreased frequency of bowel movements?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with decreased stool frequency in the setting of multiple medications, including a newly started opioid (hydrocodone). Opioids are a frequent cause of medication-induced constipation. Generally, patients are on opioids for a longer duration, often ≥7 days before they develop opioid-induced constipation. In addition, there should be an obvious correlation of timing, where constipation begins or worsens after starting the opioid. This patient is on iron supplements which are known to cause constipation. This patient’s decreased stool frequency began before starting the opioid, making ferrous sulfate a more likely cause of her constipation.

Constipation refers to decreased stool frequency or significant difficulty passing stool. Medication-induced constipation is a common form of constipation. Opioids are the most common medication that cause constipation. However several other medications such as calcium channel blockers (e.g. amlodipine), antidepressants, iron supplements, and agents with anticholinergic properties (e.g., diphenhydramine, oxybutynin) may also cause constipation. If feasible, the culprit medication should be discontinued and swapped out for a medication with a different mode of action, or if possible the dose should be decreased. Lifestyle modifications should be reinforced including increasing fluid intake and physical exercise, and other medications (such as osmotic or stimulant laxatives) may need to be added.

Option Analysis

❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin can cause diarrhea as a side effect, however it does not typically cause constipation.  
✅ Ferrous sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hydrocodone-acetaminophen:
Incorrect: While opioids frequently cause medication-induced constipation, this patient has been on opioids for a short duration and is taking relatively low doses.  
❌ Amoxicillin-clavulanate:
Incorrect: Many antibiotics can cause abdominal discomfort as well as changes in bowel habits. Many antibiotics (such as this one) cause diarrhea as a side effect, not constipation.  
❌ Magnesium hydroxide:
Incorrect: This medication can be used as an antacid and for constipation. It may cause diarrhea, and does not typically cause constipation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman returns to the primary care office with continued symptoms of intermittent constipation after a recent four-week trial of fiber supplementation and stimulant laxatives. She has experienced symptoms of constipation intermittently for the last ten years. There is no abdominal pain, weight loss, or blood in the stools. Cancer screening is up-to-date. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not routinely take medications. She has a pregnancy history of three spontaneous vaginal deliveries and one cesarean section after prolonged labor. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. There is no tenderness on rectal exam, and there are no lesions or masses. Given her pregnancy and delivery history, dyssynergic defecation, or difficulty expelling stool, is the suspected cause. Which of the following should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely experiencing dyssynergic defecation, and initial testing with anorectal manometry would provide an objective evaluation of the strength and coordination of the muscles surrounding the anal sphincter. Dyssynergic defecation involves difficulty with bowel movements or the inability to expel stool from the anorectum. These issues can lead to primary constipation, especially in older individuals and patients with chronic constipation or injury or repeated strain of the pelvic floor musculature as can be seen with vaginal deliveries.

Primary causes of constipation should be suspected in patients without red flag symptoms and no identified secondary cause of constipation. Failure of empiric treatment or signs and symptoms of a specific primary etiology should prompt further workup with diagnostic testing. Anorectal manometry and balloon expulsion testing are common initial studies. If testing is abnormal, then a defecatory disorder can be diagnosed. If testing is inconclusive but suspicion for a defecatory disorder remains high, defecography can be performed; this uses imaging to observe a barium solution as it is passed through the rectum.

A colonic transit study is used to evaluate for normal transit vs slow transit constipation. In this test, radiopaque markers are tracked through the gastrointestinal tract using X-rays. The amount of time it takes for the markers to pass is measured, and if the transit time is prolonged, then slow transit constipation can be diagnosed. The results of testing are then used to guide management. Colonoscopy should be performed if patients have failed conventional therapy, have red flags signs and symptoms, or have not had age-appropriate screening.

Option Analysis

✅ Anorectal manometry:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonic transit study:
Incorrect: A colonic transit study would help in differentiating normal vs slow transit constipation but would not provide information about the functioning of the anal sphincter or pelvic musculature.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Endoscopic evaluation would not help provide objective information regarding functioning of the anal sphincter or pelvic musculature.  
❌ Defecography:
Incorrect: Defecography can be ordered when anal manometry or balloon expulsion testing is inconclusive for diagnosing anal sphincter dysfunction, but it is not typically the initial study ordered.  
❌ No further testing is warranted:
Incorrect: Given the failure of empiric treatment, further testing is warranted to manage this patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to diarrhea and abdominal cramps for the last 4 months. She has had on average 5 bowel movements daily. The stool is watery and contains mucus but no blood. She has also noticed that her cramps are relieved after each bowel movement. The patient has not experienced weight loss, fever, or change in appetite. Past medical history is significant for migraine headaches, for which she occasionally takes acetaminophen. The patient does not take any other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing, imaging, and colonoscopy results are normal. She is diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome and prescribed loperamide. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action in reducing diarrhea?

choices.text: Reduction of colonic peristalsis by inhibiting the release of excitatory neurotransmitters in the myenteric plexus
Inhibition of colonic migrating motor complex with resultant slowing of colonic contraction
Inhibition of cytokine release and reduction of colonic wall inflammation
Inhibition of muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the enteric plexus and smooth muscles

questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal cramps and diarrhea. She is diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and started on loperamide.

Loperamide is an opioid agonist that exerts its antidiarrheal effects by binding to and activating μ-opiate receptors in the enteric nervous system. Activation of the μ-receptors in the colon inhibits the release of excitatory neurotransmitters (acetylcholine) from the myenteric nerve plexus, which in turn decreases peristalsis, slows colonic motility, and allows more water to be absorbed. Ultimately, loperamide reduces stool volume, increases viscosity, and diminishes fluid loss.

Loperamide is used to treat IBS-diarrhea and chemotherapy-associated diarrhea as well as decrease ileostomy output. It undergoes significant first-pass hepatic metabolism, resulting in very low plasma levels. Furthermore, loperamide has poor blood-brain barrier penetration and as a result, has negligible central nervous system manifestations and low potential for addiction or tolerance. It may cause mild cramps and, when taken in high doses, rebound constipation.

Diphenoxylate is another opioid agonist that is sometimes used to treat IBS diarrhea. At low doses, diphenoxylate does not cross the blood-brain barrier. However, it does at higher doses. To reduce the likelihood of abuse, it is frequently mixed with atropine, which exerts unpleasant anticholinergic symptoms (e.g., dry mouth, dry eyes) when taken in higher amounts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reduction of colonic peristalsis by inhibiting the release of excitatory neurotransmitters in the myenteric plexus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of colonic migrating motor complex with resultant slowing of colonic contraction:
Incorrect: Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem, verapamil) are sometimes associated with constipation due to inhibition of colonic migrating motor complexes and slowing of colonic contraction.  
❌ Inhibition of cytokine release and reduction of colonic wall inflammation:
Incorrect: Steroids are used in inflammatory bowel diseases (e.g. ulcerative colitis) to reduce inflammation of the intestinal walls and decrease inflammatory cytokines release. Steroids have no role in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome since there is no underlying inflammation.  
❌ Inhibition of muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the enteric plexus and smooth muscles:
Incorrect: Hyoscyamine and dicyclomine are antispasmodics that are used in patients with irritable bowel syndrome to relieve abdominal pain or discomfort. These anticholinergic drugs inhibit muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the enteric plexus and smooth muscles.  
❌ Reduction of intestinal fluid secretion:
Incorrect: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is sometimes used to treat secretory diarrhea by reducing intestinal fluid secretion. It also inhibits the release of numerous hormones in the gastrointestinal tract and decreases gallbladder contraction.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man presents to the primary care office due to recurrent bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence for the past several months. His stools have mostly been a watery liquid consistency, and his symptoms are worse after meals. He recently started training to become a competitive bodybuilder and has been on a diet consisting of milk and whey protein shakes, yogurt, and red meat at every meal. He has not had recent illnesses, nocturnal diarrheal symptoms, or recent weight loss. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes only multivitamins. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds without tenderness to palpation. Stool osmotic gap is 110 mOsm/kg. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of watery diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence that occur after the intake of lactulose-containing foods (e.g., milkshakes, and yogurt), are indicative of lactose intolerance.         

Lactose intolerance occurs due to a deficiency in lactase, the enzyme responsible for breaking down lactose in the small intestine. The undigested lactose is fermented by colonic bacteria, producing hydrogen gas and organic acids, which can be detected by an increase in breath hydrogen content and a decrease in stool pH. The hydrogen breath test is a non-invasive diagnostic tool that can be used to help identify lactose intolerance when the diagnosis is not apparent from the clinical evaluation and a trial of dairy avoidance.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Fecal bile acid level:
Incorrect:   An elevated fecal bile acid level is associated with diarrhea caused by over-production or insufficient absorption of bile acids that lead to a secretory type of diarrhea. This patient’s elevated osmotic gap is more suggestive of osmotic diarrhea from lactose intolerance, which can be confirmed with a hydrogen breath test if needed.    
❌ Fecal pancreatic elastase-1 level :
Incorrect: Fecal pancreatic elastase-1 level measures pancreatic function and is used to diagnose pancreatic insufficiency, which typically presents with steatorrhea and malabsorption, not with the symptoms described in this patient, which are more consistent with lactose intolerance. 
✅ Hydrogen breath test:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tissue transglutaminase IgA level:
Incorrect: Tissue transglutaminase IgA level is a serological test used to diagnose celiac disease, which is caused by gluten intolerance and often presents with steatorrhea, weight loss, and evidence of malabsorption. This patient’s watery diarrhea after intake of dairy products is more suggestive of lactose intolerance, which can be confirmed with a hydrogen breath test.  
❌ 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid level:
Incorrect: The 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid testing is used to diagnose carcinoid syndrome, which can be associated with flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing due to serotonin production by carcinoid tumors. This patient’s isolated intestinal symptoms after eating milk-containing products and elevated stool osmotic gap are more suggestive of osmotic diarrhea caused by lactose intolerance.

questions.text: A G2P0A1 32-year-old woman at 28 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician’s office due to difficulty passing stool and associated abdominal cramps. She has 2-3 bowel movements per week and strains significantly to pass very hard stool. These symptoms started 2 weeks ago, are accompanied by bloating, and are partially relieved with defecation. Drinking more than 4 ounces of water in an hour causes significant nausea and abdominal cramping. Physical examination of the patient and fetal ultrasound are both normal. After counseling the patient on lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate next medication for this patient’s constipation?
questions.solution:
A significant percentage of women experience constipation during pregnancy. Docusate is an emollient stool softener. The molecular structure of stool softeners includes a hydrophilic polar end and a hydrophobic non-polar end. This allows docusate to facilitate dishesion of fatty stool and allow for water penetration, making the stool softer. Other examples of emollient stool softeners include glycerin and mineral oil. Docusate does not have adverse effects in pregnancy and is therefore generally considered to be safe. While very safe and well-tolerated, it is important to note, however, that in recent years the effectiveness of docusate has been called into question more and more. A side effect of all long-term emollient stool softener use is intermittent diarrhea. Docusate is often used in combination formulations with senna to treat opioid-induced constipation. Glycerin, which is often delivered as a rectal suppository and with rectal enemas, has been shown to irritate the anal mucosa.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Docusate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Psyllium:
Incorrect: Psyllium is a bulk-forming laxative. The bulk-forming laxatives absorb water, distending the intestinal wall and promoting peristalsis. While the bulk-forming laxatives are first-line therapy for most constipation, they need to be consumed with a lot of water, which this patient cannot tolerate.  
❌ Senna:
Incorrect: While senna (and other stimulating agents) can be very useful in constipation, senna would not be appropriate in this case. This patient’s bowels are already quite active and her stool is very hard and difficult to pass. Increasing peristalsis with a stimulating agent would just add to the discomfort.  
❌ Lubiprostone:
Incorrect: Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator, which draws chloride into the intestinal lumen and creates an osmotic gradient, drawing water into the lumen. It is not first-line therapy for constipation and, more importantly, is pregnancy category C.  
❌ Bran:
Incorrect: Bran is a bulk-forming laxative. The bulk-forming laxatives absorb water, distending the intestinal wall and promoting peristalsis. While the bulk-forming laxatives are first-line therapy for most constipation, they need to be consumed with a lot of water, which this patient cannot tolerate.

questions.text: A 7-day-old baby boy born at 27 weeks is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) and found to have high gastric residuals, fever, lethargy and bloody stools. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.6 °C (101.5 °F), heart rate of 172/min, respiratory rate of 55/min, and blood pressure of 65/35 mmHg. Exam is notable for a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds. There is abdominal tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants without rebound or guarding. There are no anal fissures or abscesses. Which of the following clinical findings would be most indicative of the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most preterm infants who develop necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) have a history of being healthy, feeding well, and growing appropriately before developing NEC. The most common initial sign is a change in feeding tolerance. The typical initial presentation of NEC is the development of feeding intolerance, abdominal distention, and bloody stools after 8 to 10 days of age.

The clinical presentation of NEC can be variable and can range from subtle to severe. Nonspecific findings can be seen, including fever, lethargy, apneic episodes, bradycardia, hypotension, and poor glucose homeostasis. However, the most common presenting sign is a change in feeding tolerance. Any preterm neonate with gastrointestinal symptoms or signs who has feeding intolerance should be evaluated for NEC. Patients suspected of NEC should have abdominal imaging performed.

Symptoms may progress rapidly, often within hours, from subtle signs to abdominal discoloration, intestinal perforation, and peritonitis, which can lead to systemic hypotension that requires intensive medical support, surgical support, or both. Early imaging signs that should raise suspicion of necrotizing enterocolitis include dilated loops of the bowel, a paucity of bowel gas, and gas-filled loops of the bowel that are unaltered on repeated examinations. Extraluminal air (“free air”) outside the bowel is a sign of advanced necrotizing enterocolitis. Pathognomonic findings for NEC on abdominal radiography include pneumatosis intestinalis and portal venous gas.  

Option Analysis

❌ Apnea:
Incorrect: Apnea can be seen with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), but it also may be seen with respiratory and circulatory conditions. The most common initial sign of NEC is a change in feeding tolerance.  
❌ Lethargy:
Incorrect: Lethargy can be seen in patients with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) due to dehydration or sepsis. However, this finding is not specific to  necrotizing enterocolitis and can be seen with many other conditions including infectious and noninfectious causes. The most common initial sign of NEC is a change in feeding tolerance.  
✅ Change in feeding tolerance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: Fever is a nonspecific sign that can be associated with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC); however, it can be caused by many other conditions as well. The most common initial sign of NEC is a change in feeding tolerance.  
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Hypotension resulting from septic shock may be seen in severe cases of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). 20 to 30 percent of infants with NEC develop bacteremia, which may lead to hypotension and sepsis. However, the most common initial sign of NEC is a change in feeding tolerance.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with his parents for evaluation of several months of worsening constipation and fatigue. The patient has tried limiting dairy and increasing fruit and fiber in his diet. Over-the-counter laxatives were also tried with minimal improvement in symptoms. The patient reports intermittent abdominal pain and vomiting. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and he has received all age-appropriate well-childcare. Weight is 8th percentile and height is 12th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a well-appearing boy in no acute distress. Abdomen is soft and nontender, there are normoactive bowel sounds, and stool is palpated in the left lower quadrant. Rectal examination does not demonstrate evidence of fissures, hemorrhoids, masses, or fecal impaction. There is an itchy papular vesicular rash on the extensor surfaces of the patient’s knees. Which of the following would likely be present on further questioning?

choices.text: History of delayed passage of meconium
Exposure to a home built in 1956 in the United States

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of constipation that has persisted despite dietary modifications and laxative therapy. The patient’s short stature, intermittent abdominal pain and vomiting, and dermatitis herpetiformis rash make celiac disease the likely diagnosis. Upon further questioning, this patient may report noticing a sensitivity to gluten. 

A focused history and physical examination for a pediatric patient with constipation is important. The history begins with an assessment of the frequency of bowel movements, ease of defecation, and stool consistency. The Bristol stool chart can be used by patients to identify stool consistency.

It is important to ask about medication or toxin exposure associated with constipation. Specifically, patients and families should be questioned regarding potential opiates, antacid, iron, or lead exposure. A review of systems should include questions about systemic symptoms, such as fatigue, rashes, or cold intolerance. A patient’s growth chart can also provide information regarding the underlying cause of constipation.

On physical examination, assessment should include auscultation and palpation of the abdomen. In patients with constipation, stool is often palpated in the left lower abdominal quadrant. A perianal examination is important at all ages, and in newborns, a digital rectal examination should be performed. A neurological examination offers information regarding whether a spinal cord abnormality is causing constipation. Physical examinations should be thorough and include dermatologic and thyroid evaluations.   

Option Analysis

✅ Sensitivity to gluten:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of delayed passage of meconium:
Incorrect: Timing of meconium passage is a key historical element when constipation presents in the newborn period. This patient is 16 years old and has a rash consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the likely cause of constipation and fatigue.  
❌ Family history of neurologic disease:
Incorrect: Neurologic diseases such as Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis can be associated with constipation. However, this patient is young and does not have any signs or symptoms of neurologic disease. This patient likely has dermatitis herpetiformis on examination, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the likely cause of constipation and fatigue. 
❌ Cold intolerance:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause constipation and cold intolerance. However, this patient likely has dermatitis herpetiformis on examination, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Exposure to a home built in 1956 in the United States:
Incorrect: The United States passed legislation in 1978 banning the manufacture of lead-based house paint. Exposure to a home built before this time increases the risk of lead poisoning. High levels of lead can cause gastrointestinal symptoms, such as constipation. This patient's age and lack of other symptoms makes lead poisoning unlikely. This patient has dermatitis herpetiformis on examination, making celiac disease and a reaction to gluten the more likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea for three days. The pain is severe and crampy in the left lower quadrant. She reports multiple bloody bowel movements and fecal urgency. The patient was diagnosed with Crohn disease at nine and has been in remission for two years. Past surgical and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen without distension. The exam is otherwise normal. Labs are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     8.9 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     34 %    
 Leukocyte count     14,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     350,000/mm3    
 C-reactive protein      104 mg/L    
 Albumin      2.8 g/dL    
 Fecal calprotectin      3000 µg/g
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of Crohn disease presents with an acute exacerbation as evidenced by severe abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. This patient is hemodynamically unstable, as evidenced by the tachycardia and hypotension. The first step in management involves administering intravenous fluids.        

Patients with acute exacerbations of Crohn disease present with diffuse, crampy, periumbilical pain, bloody stools, and fecal urgency. Some patients might demonstrate extraintestinal manifestations like arthritis, uveitis, and skin nodules or ulcers. There may be a family history of inflammatory bowel disease. Physical examination usually demonstrates abdominal tenderness and, sometimes, cutaneous findings like erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum, or psoriatic lesions. Patients diagnosed with Crohn disease may experience an acute exacerbation which can be a life-threatening medical emergency and can lead to serious complications such as fistulas or bowel obstruction.        

A pediatric patient experiencing an acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease requires immediate ABCDE assessment for airway, breathing, and circulation stabilization. Rapid intravenous fluid administration is crucial in cases of hemodynamic instability. Other essential components of initial management include continuous vital sign monitoring and application of supplemental oxygen, as needed. Once stabilized, corticosteroid therapy should be initiated.   

Option Analysis

❌ Perform colonoscopy  :
Incorrect: While colonoscopy is the diagnostic tool of choice for inflammatory bowel disease, this patient is unstable, and the priority is stabilization with administration of intravenous fluids. 
❌ Administer methylprednisone  :
Incorrect: While methylprednisone is the treatment of choice for an acute exacerbation of inflammatory bowel disease, this patient is unstable and requires stabilization with intravenous fluids.  
✅ Administer intravenous fluids  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform fecal occult blood test  :
Incorrect: This patient has a known inflammatory bowel disease and will likely have a positive fecal occult blood test. Regardless, it is important to stabilize the patient before performing diagnostic testing. 
❌ Consult surgery  :
Incorrect: Surgical consultation is indicated for patients with inflammatory bowel disease in cases of intractable hemorrhage, perforation, toxic megacolon, or unresponsive to medical management. This patient is unstable and requires stabilization with intravenous fluids first.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to a clinic with abdominal pain and diarrhea for 6 months. He has had 3-5 non-bloody, loose stools per day with bloating. His symptoms are worse after eating wheat and barley products. He has also developed an associated skin rash. He does not have hematochezia, melena, weight loss, or a family history of gastrointestinal disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/69 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the abdomen is mildly distended with no tenderness or rigidity. Biopsy via esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) demonstrates villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia. Which of the following best describes the type of rash that would be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Erythematous target lesions with a dusky center
Erythematous macular lesion with a pale center

questions.solution:
Dermatitis herpetiform. Reproduced from: Wikipedia. Licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0.    

This patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and bloating. Endoscopic biopsy demonstrates villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia consistent with celiac disease. Dermatitis herpetiformis refers to an itchy, grouped papulovesicular rash that typically appears on the elbows and knees. It is commonly seen in patients with celiac disease.        

Celiac disease is an immune-mediated systemic disorder elicited by ingestion of gluten, which is found in wheat, barley, and rye. Celiac disease can occur at any age, from infancy to late childhood. Symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, anorexia, and abdominal distension. Failure to thrive and severe malnutrition can also be seen—particularly in patients with a delayed diagnosis. Extraintestinal findings include short stature and dermatitis herpetiformis, which typically manifests as a grouped papulovesicular rash over the elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior scalp. Excoriated vesicles may be seen secondary to the associated pruritus.       

In celiac disease, the total IgA will be normal, and the anti-TTG IgA will be positive. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy demonstrates villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. Treatment includes a gluten-free diet, which results in improvement of symptoms, rapid growth, and weight gain.    

Option Analysis

✅ Grouped papulovesicular lesions over the elbows :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Painful skin ulcers over the leg  :
Incorrect: Pyoderma gangrenousum is associated with inflammatory bowel disease and appears as erythematous papules that eventually ulcerate. This patient has chronic abdominal pain with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Endoscopy findings confirm the diagnosis of celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. 
❌ Erythematous plaques over the face :
Incorrect: Acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen in patients with zinc deficiency, appears as an erythematous maculopapular rash on the face; it is associated with angular stomatitis, glossitis, generalized alopecia, and diarrhea. This patient's findings are more consistent with celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. 
❌ Erythematous target lesions with a dusky center :
Incorrect: Erythema multiforme appears as an erythematous target lesion with a dusky center. This condition is commonly associated with viruses, medications, and autoimmune diseases. The findings in this patient are more consistent with celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. 
❌ Erythematous macular lesion with a pale center  :
Incorrect: Erythema marginatum appears as erythematous macular lesions surrounded by a slightly raised border with a pale center. This condition is commonly associated with acute rheumatic fever. The findings in this patient are more consistent with celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of vomiting for two months. The vomiting is sporadic, non-bilious, and non-bloody, typically occurring after meals. The patient also reports occasional diarrhea, bloating, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Parents are concerned because of unintentional weight loss of 3 kg (6.6 lbs.). Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus, diagnosed one year ago, which has been well-controlled. Growth is at the 15th percentile for weight and the 25th percentile for height. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals abdominal distension but no tenderness or organomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     11.0 g/dL    
 Mean corpuscular volume     74 fL    
 Serum glucose     145 mg/dL    
 Serum sodium     139 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     4.0 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     23 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient's recurrent vomiting, diarrhea, weight loss, bloating, and history of type 1 diabetes mellitus suggest celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder in which ingestion of gluten triggers an immune response that damages the small intestine lining, leading to malabsorption. The patient’s laboratory findings further support this diagnosis, as iron deficiency anemia is commonly associated with celiac disease. The next step is to measure serum anti-TTG IgA, the preferred screening test. If positive, biopsy confirmation via esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is recommended.        

The diagnostic workup for a pediatric patient with vomiting starts with a focused history and physical examination. Acute vomiting with bilious emesis may indicate intestinal obstruction from conditions like superior mesenteric artery syndrome or pancreatitis, which can be differentiated through imaging and laboratory studies. Diarrhea may suggest infectious gastroenteritis, which can be confirmed with stool studies.        

Chronic vomiting with a change in bowel habits may point to constipation or celiac disease. Celiac disease is diagnosed with total IgA and anti-TTG IgA levels and EGD with biopsy. Vomiting related to food intake may indicate eosinophilic esophagitis or gastroparesis, which are diagnosable with EGD or gastric emptying study, respectively. Episodic early morning vomiting suggests cyclic vomiting syndrome or increased intracranial pressure, which require Rome IV criteria or neuroimaging. Vomiting related to food or fluid intake may also indicate an eating disorder or uteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, diagnosable with a validated screening tool or renal ultrasound, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound is not useful for diagnosing celiac disease. It may be indicated to assess for structural abnormalities or obstruction, but these are not suggested by this patient’s presentation.
✅ Serum anti-TTG IgA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastric emptying study:
Incorrect: A gastric emptying study is used to diagnose gastroparesis, which presents with early satiety, nausea, and abdominal distension. This patient is at increased risk of gastroparesis due to underlying type 1 diabetes. However, it typically requires years of poor glycemic control to develop, which is not present here. 
❌ Stool culture and ova/parasite  :
Incorrect: The patient’s chronic symptoms and lack of fever, acute diarrhea, or travel history make an infectious etiology unlikely.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal series:
Incorrect: An upper GI series is used to assess for mechanical obstructions or motility disorders but does not provide sufficient diagnostic information for celiac disease.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents for evaluation of 1 day of progressively worsening abdominal pain. The parents report that he has had mild intermittent abdominal pain over the last month, but today the pain is worse than in the past month. It is now limiting his activity. The patient has had a noticeable decrease in appetite over the past 24 hours but. He has been drinking well with good urine output. There is no change in urinary frequency or urine appearance. He stools 1-2 times per week and occasionally the stools are hard pellets. Weight is at the 48th percentile and height is at the 57th percentile. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 118/min, blood pressure is 93/50 mm Hg, respirations are 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. The abdomen is mildly distended with normoactive bowel sounds. There is mild mid-abdominal tenderness without rigidity. A mass is palpated in the lower left quadrant of the abdomen. There is no right lower quadrant tenderness and there is no rebound, guarding, or hepatosplenomegaly. The testicles are descended with appropriate cremasteric reflex bilaterally. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 4-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain for 24 hours and a decreased activity level, as well as decreased appetite. The patient has infrequent hard stools and is found to have a palpable mass in the left lower abdomen, without right lower quadrant tenderness, rebound or guarding. These findings are consistent with constipation. The best next step in managing constipation in this stable patient is to administer a laxative medication like polyethylene glycol. The most common causes of acute abdominal pain in children are acute gastroenteritis and acute constipation.        

The first step in managing pediatric patients with abdominal pain is to perform an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment and stabilize the patient if necessary. Patients with an acute surgical abdomen are typically unstable. Treatment may include obtaining intravenous access for fluid resuscitation, limiting oral intake, and nasogastric tube placement. If there is concern for infectious etiology, broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics should be initiated.        

Importantly, patients with abdominal exam should always be assessed for signs, symptoms, and physical exam findings of acute surgical abdomen, including sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, rebound tenderness, guarding, and abdominal distention with rigidity. When these peritoneal signs are present, patients should have a surgical consultation. The most common causes of acute abdomen in children are acute appendicitis and bowel obstruction from volvulus or iոtսѕѕսѕϲеptiοn.  



Option Analysis

✅ Administer polyethylene glycol:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Order abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer polyethylene glycol. Constipation is often a clinical diagnosis, and treatment can be initiated without confirmatory imaging. 
❌ Start intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics should be started when there is high suspicion for a bacterial process. Empiric intravenous antibiotics may be initiated in the emergency department after cultures are obtained or earlier if the patient is unstable. This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation; therefore, antibiotics are not necessary.  
❌ Consult pediatric surgery:
Incorrect: Pediatric surgery should be consulted when patients present with an acute surgical abdomen (e.g., signs of peritonitis). This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation and not an acute abdomen. The most appropriate next step in management of constipation is to start polyethylene glycol. 
❌ Make status nothing by mouth (NPO):
Incorrect: Patients are made NPO, when there is concern for an acute surgical abdomen with impending surgery or if there is repeated emesis. The patient does not have either of these findings. This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation for which polyethylene glycol can be started.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to a clinic for evaluation of abdominal pain and intermittent bloody diarrhea for the past 3 months. The pain is described as generalized, severe, and crampy. The pain is not diurnal or related to food consumption. She reports sores in her mouth and unexpected weight loss over the past few months. The patient has not had a fever, rash, or mucoid stool. Menstrual cycles are regular, and she is not sexually active. Past medical, surgical, and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 117/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On exam, she has ulcers over the buccal mucosa and tender nodules over her legs as shown in the image below. The abdomen is tender about the umbilicus and over the left lower quadrant, and there is no distention or rigidity. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Which of the following laboratory tests should be ordered as part of this patient’s workup? 



Reproduced from Wikimedia . Licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, bloody stools, and weight loss with physical exam findings of oral ulcers and erythema nodosum; this presentation is consistent with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), likely Crohn disease. A fecal calprotectin level and colonoscopy with biopsies should be ordered.       

Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) report diffuse, crampy, periumbilical pain and fecal urgency. These symptoms are often associated with bloody stools, weight loss, or suboptimal weight gain. Some patients demonstrate extraintestinal manifestations like arthritis, episcleritis and uveitis, and skin nodules or ulcers. There may also be a family history of inflammatory bowel disease. Physical exam usually demonstrates abdominal tenderness, skin findings such as erythema nodosum (painful nodules over the tibia), and pyoderma gangrenousum (ulcerative lesions on the lower extremities).        

Patients with chronic abdominal pain, bloody stools, and weight loss should be evaluated for IBD. IBD is diagnosed in a patient with an elevated fecal calprotectin. To help differentiate the etiology of the IBD, a colonoscopy with biopsies should be performed. There are two types of IBD: ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn disease. UC shows a continuous pattern of edematous, erythematous, friable mucosa and erosions or ulcerations in the colon; biopsy reveals mucosal and submucosal inflammation with erosions, ulcerations, and crypt abscesses. In contrast, Crohn disease demonstrates cobblestoning, a discontinuous pattern of skip lesions, and linear serpiginous ulcerations. Crohn disease can involve the entire gastrointestinal tract, with rectal sparing. A biopsy will show transmural inflammation and granulomas.  

Option Analysis

❌ Esophageal pH monitoring :
Incorrect: Esophageal pH monitoring is a diagnostic test for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which presents with heartburn, anorexia, and epigastric/chest pain. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease, and fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm that diagnosis.  
✅ Fecal calprotectin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) :
Incorrect: GGT is the test of choice for diagnosis of biliary disease, which presents with jaundice and abdominal pain. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease. Fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Hydrogen breath test  :
Incorrect: The hydrogen breath test is useful for the diagnosis of lactase deficiency, which presents with abdominal pain, flatulence, and diarrhea related to consuming lactose-containing foods. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease; fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm that diagnosis.  
❌ Total IgA :
Incorrect: Total IgA is a diagnostic test for celiac disease, which presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and steatorrhea secondary to gluten sensitivity. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease, and fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the family medicine clinic accompanied by his parent due to a 4-week history of infrequent bowel movements. According to the parent, the child has had 2 bowel movements per week during which he strains. Previously, the child had one bowel movement per day. The patient has not had any abdominal pain or change in stool caliber or consistency. The patient feels pain while defecating and notices red streaks while wiping. The child takes no medications, is obese with a BMI of 32, and is otherwise healthy. The child started primary school 3 weeks ago. When asked about exercise, the parent states that he plays video games most of the day and goes for a short walk in the evening with the other parent. The child’s diet consists of fruits, vegetables, and meats. When asked if he drinks water during the day, the child shakes his head and says no. Which of the following is likely to contribute most to the child’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has a chief complaint of infrequent bowel movements. While there are defined criteria for defining constipation, such as the Rome III criteria and the Bristol stool scale, they are more often used in medical research than in clinical diagnosis. Typically, clinical constipation is defined as having fewer than 3 bowel movements per week.

This patient experiences pain while defecating and notices blood while wiping. These symptoms are characteristic of anal fissures. With prolonged constipation and subsequent hardening of stool, anal fissures can develop with forceful straining and anal distention. These fissures cause pain while defecating and deter efforts to have a bowel movement. Voluntary withholding then worsens constipation, and a cyclical pattern develops. Voluntary withholding (due to pain or other biopsychosocial causes) is a major cause of constipation in children.  

Option Analysis

❌ Recently starting primary school:
Incorrect: Functional constipation (constipation arising from an unknown etiology) is common in children and has been associated with several biopsychosocial risk factors. While recently starting primary school introduces new psychological stressors on the child, this explanation is unlikely since he started having symptoms one week before starting school.  
✅ Pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: While there are several risk factors associated with both obesity and constipation, such as long-term sedentary lifestyles and low-fiber diets, no direct association between obesity and constipation exists. Rather than developing constipation, overweight and obese adolescents may be more likely to have fecal incontinence.  
❌ Lack of exercise:
Incorrect: There is a long-held belief that bowel frequency increases in proportion to increased exercise; however, these findings are not evidence-based. Physical exercise has been shown to dramatically increase physical fitness; however, no consistent effect on large bowel function has been found. Therefore, while this patient should partake in more daily exercise, it should not have an impact on his recent symptoms of constipation.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Constipation is reported in nearly 60% of adults with diabetes mellitus. The cause of constipation remains poorly understood and likely involves long-term autonomic and enteric neuropathy. Patients with diabetes frequently suffer from enteropathic diarrhea and bloating due to the same pathophysiology. The child in this vignette has neither been diagnosed with diabetes nor does he present with any classical symptoms of diabetes such as polyuria, polydipsia, polyphasia or fatigue. Children with new-onset diabetes frequently present with nocturnal enuresis.

questions.text: A 2-week-old baby girl born at 28 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for low blood pressure. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and the mother took prenatal vitamins throughout. At birth, the baby weighed 1.7 kg and had been progressing well in the NICU, tolerating enteral feeds. Today, she appears lethargic and has had blood in the stool. Temperature is 100.3°F (38 °C), heart rate is 155/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, and blood pressure is 60/32 mmHg. The patient is sleeping but can be aroused and is moving all four extremities. Exam is notable for decreased bowel sounds, diffuse abdominal distention, and generalized tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. Abdominal radiographs are obtained which reveal a small area of pneumatosis intestinalis without evidence of pneumoperitoneum. Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue enteral feeds and administer IV fluids
Continue enteral feeds, gastric decompression via orogastric tube, and administer IV fluids
Hold enteral feeds, gastric decompression via an orogastric tube, administer IV fluids and IV antibiotics
Emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy
Emergent interventional radiology consultation for peritoneal drain placement

questions.solution:
This premature infant in the NICU with low birth weight presents with a change in feeding tolerance, bloody stools, abdominal pain and distension, and an abdominal x-ray showing pneumatosis intestinalis. These findings are consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and medical management alone is the appropriate initial management for this patient who appears stable without evidence of severe disease or pneumoperitoneum on abdominal x-ray. Medical management consists of withholding enteral feedings, gastric decompression, administering intravenous fluid and intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, and obtaining central intravenous access (often with a peripherally inserted central catheter).

Patients diagnosed with necrotizing enterocolitis should be evaluated for hemodynamic stability or instability and severity of symptoms and findings on abdominal x-rays. This patient is hypotensive, but this may respond to initial IV fluids and there are no findings of peritonitis on exam, nor does the abdominal film show evidence of pneumoperitoneum. Therefore, he does not require emergent surgical consultation at this time.

There is no standard duration for antimicrobial therapy for necrotizing enterocolitis, but treatment typically ranges from 7 to 14 days. Similarly, there are no standard antimicrobial agents used to treat NEC, but therapy often initially includes broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic bacteria. Surgery is reserved for unstable patients with pneumoperitoneum or a paracentesis consistent with enteric contents, or for those patients who deteriorate clinically with medical management.

Option Analysis

❌ Continue enteral feeds and administer IV fluids:
Incorrect: This patient with a change in feeding tolerance and hematochezia who is found to have pneumatosis intestinalis can be diagnosed with necrotizing enterocolitis. Enteral feeds should be held and treatment should include gastric decompression via an orogastric tube, IV fluids which can improve the patient’s blood pressure, and antibiotics.  
❌ Continue enteral feeds, gastric decompression via orogastric tube, and administer IV fluids:
Incorrect: When necrotizing enterocolitis is diagnosed, enteral feeds should be held and gastric decompression should be initiated, usually via an orogastric tube, and IV fluids and antibiotics should also be given.  
✅ Hold enteral feeds, gastric decompression via an orogastric tube, administer IV fluids and IV antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention for necrotizing enterocolitis occurs in up to 50% of patients. Pneumoperitoneum or a paracentesis showing enteric contents are absolute indications for surgical intervention. If the patient appears unstable and has extensive pneumatosis, surgery should also be considered. This patient appears stable and has a small amount of pneumatosis; therefore, medical management is more appropriate.  
❌ Emergent interventional radiology consultation for peritoneal drain placement:
Incorrect: In patients who have necrotizing enterocolitis and are unstable with evidence of hollow viscus perforation, a primary peritoneal drain placement can be performed at the bedside. A peritoneal drain serves as a temporary measure, as up to 75% of patients end up requiring definitive surgery. It is not necessary for this patient who has no evidence of perforation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician accompanied by his parents for evaluation of ongoing issues with stooling. Parents report the patient has had difficulty passing stool for the past two months and appears to be straining while having bowel movements. They report, on average, less than two bowel movements per week. When the patient does pass stool, it is “large in diameter” and hurts. He is toilet trained but is refusing to sit on the toilet due to pain with stooling. There are no complaints of abdominal pain and no systemic symptoms. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. The patient first stooled at 36 hours of life. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and he has received all appropriate pediatric well-childcare. Dietary changes have been implemented, but no other intervention has been tried. Vital signs are within normal limits. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Physical examination demonstrates a well-appearing boy in no acute distress. Abdomen is soft and nontender, there are normoactive bowel sounds, and stool is palpated in the left lower quadrant. Rectal examination does not demonstrate evidence of fissures, hemorrhoids, masses, or fecal impaction. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start a behavior modification program (e.g. rewards for the patient sitting on the toilet)

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy pediatric patient presents for evaluation of constipation and does not have stigmata or red flag features suggestive of endocrine, medication-induced, or autoimmune conditions. This patient meets several criteria for functional constipation via the Rome criteria. The most important initial step in management of constipation is starting an oral laxative.

Constipation refers to an abnormal stooling pattern associated with hard stools and incomplete, infrequent, or painful defecation. The stooling pattern in healthy infants is highly variable. By four years of age, most healthy children pass one normally formed stool daily or every other day. Constipation in this age group is more likely to represent a functional gastrointestinal disorder. Functional constipation is a diagnosis of exclusion and can only be diagnosed using the Rome criteria once other organic causes of constipation are ruled out.

Acute management of pediatric patients with constipation first includes an assessment for any alarm features, including delayed passage of meconium, fever, vomiting, rectal bleeding, severe abdominal distension, urinary incontinence or bladder disease, weight loss or poor weight gain, or extraintestinal symptoms. Functional constipation in children is best managed with oral laxative therapy, behavioral modification, dietary changes, and disimpaction with rectal medications when necessary. Behavioral modification should be started after the oral laxative treatment has begun. Disimpaction with rectal medication is indicated in only severe cases (e.g. constipation-associated fecal incontinence) because it is invasive and can be difficult to administer to a fearful child.   

Option Analysis

✅ Start an oral laxative:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Obtain an abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation. Confirmation with an abdominal X-ray is not necessary. This patient requires treatment starting with an oral laxative. 
❌ Start a behavior modification program (e.g. rewards for the patient sitting on the toilet) :
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation. Although a behavior modification plan is often necessary to aid in bowel retraining and maintenance in cases of constipation, acute management should start with an oral laxative. 
❌ Refer to pediatric gastroenterology:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation. Besides dietary changes, no intervention has been tried yet. The first step in managing uncomplicated constipation is to start an oral laxative. If outpatient management is unsuccessful or there are any red flags, the patient should be referred to pediatric gastroenterology. 
❌ Administer an enema:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with constipation. The first step in managing uncomplicated constipation is to start an oral laxative. Enemas are reserved for cases of severe constipation (e.g. constipation-associated fecal incontinence), especially when there is a history of pain (and associated fear) with stooling.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of one-day of vomiting and passing bloody stools. The parents report the patient was in his usual state of health until earlier in the day when he started vomiting, a green-colored emesis. The stools appear mucoid and look like “currant jelly.” The parents report the patient has been intermittently fussy. The patient was born full-term and has no significant past medical history. There are no known sick contacts, exposure to unusual foods, or new medications. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 148/min, blood pressure is 85/48 mm Hg, respirations are 34/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is fussy, pale, and is lying supine with the knees pulled into the chest. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is nondistended, nontender, with normoactive bowel sounds. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, a 10-month-old boy, presents to the emergency department with one day of bilious emesis and “currant jelly” stools. The patient has intermittent abdominal pain that is relieved by bringing his knees to his chest. This presentation is consistent with intussusception. The initial work-up of intussusception should be an abdominal ultrasound, looking for a “target sign” (see below).        

Bilious emesis in newborns and infants is often a sign of intestinal obstruction and is an emergency. Once the patient is stabilized, they should have imaging performed. An abdominal radiograph, abdominal ultrasound, or an upper gastrointestinal contrast study may be performed depending on certain factors like symptomatology, and whether the patient is premature. Patients with intussusception, which is caused by telescoping of part of the intestine into itself will have a target sign on abdominal ultrasound. Intussusception is the most common abdominal emergency in early childhood. Projectile emesis is also a sign of obstruction (usually at the pylorus from pyloric stenosis) and abdominal ultrasound should be performed in patients with projectile emesis.        

Nonbilious emesis in children can be caused by many things. Determining whether the vomiting is sudden in onset or gradual in onset will help identify potential underlying causes. The differential includes infection, inborn errors or metabolism, and congenital adrenal hyperplasia, all of which require laboratory evaluation for formal diagnosis. If there is concern for increased intracranial pressure, imaging with computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging of the brain is recommended.    


Image. a target sign  
 with abundant mesenteric fat  
  & lymph nodes  
 centrally, consistent with an ileocolic intussusception 

Option Analysis

✅ Abdominal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient likely has intussusception, which is best diagnosed with abdominal ultrasound. Abdominal radiographs alone are not sensitive or specific for intussusception. Findings on abdominal ultrasound such as a “target sign” can support the diagnosis of intussusception. 
❌ Upper gastrointestinal contrast study:
Incorrect: This patient likely has intussusception, which is best diagnosed with abdominal ultrasound. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study is used to diagnose anatomic abnormalities such as malrotation with volvulus, but not intussusception. 
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient likely has intussusception which is best diagnosed with abdominal ultrasound. An upper endoscopy evaluates the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It can diagnose disorders such as gastroesophageal reflux, ulcers, and eosinophilic esophagitis. 
❌ Abdominal magnetic resonance enterography (MRE):
Incorrect: This patient likely has intussusception, which is best diagnosed with abdominal ultrasound. Abdominal MRE can be used to evaluate patients with suspected inflammatory bowel disease to assess for inflammation, obstructions, and associated complications.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old neonate is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, feeding intolerance, and abdominal distention. He was born at 37 weeks to a healthy, 34-year-old woman, G3P2, via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. He had been doing well until 2 days ago. A full sepsis and meningitis work-up is initiated and is unrevealing. The neonate has an episode of hematochezia 8 hours after initial evaluation. Vital signs are notable for a temperature of 38.3 °C (101 °F), heart rate of 140/min, respiratory rate of 42/min, and blood pressure of 65/40 mmHg. Lab results can be seen below. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?  

White blood cells (WBC)
15.5 x 103/µL
Absolute neutrophil count (ANC)
< 1500/µL
Hemoglobin (Hgb)
14.5 g/dL
Hematocrit (Hct)
52%
Platelets (PLT)
125,000/µL

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) Abdomen/Pelvis with IV contrast
No testing is necessary, a clinical diagnosis can be made

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with new onset fever, hematochezia, feeding intolerance, abdominal distention, and a negative sepsis workup should be evaluated for necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The next step in the evaluation of suspected NEC is an abdominal radiograph.

Abdominal radiography should be interpreted in the context of the clinical findings to diagnose NEC. There are several characteristic findings on abdominal x-ray that are seen in the majority of patients with NEC. An abnormal gas pattern with dilated loops of bowel that is consistent with ileus is typically seen in the early stages of NEC. Pneumatosis intestinalis or bubbles of gas in the wall of the small bowel is considered a pathognomonic finding for NEC. Pneumatosis in a preterm infant indicates NEC until proven otherwise. Evidence of pneumoperitoneum can be seen when bowel perforation occurs and may cause a "football" sign on a supine radiograph. Finally, portal venous gas indicating bacterial gas entering the portal system that outlines branching segments of the vascular tree may be seen.  

Option Analysis

❌ Diagnostic laparoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient has a presumed diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis given the clinical symptoms, laboratory workup, and negative sepsis workup. A diagnostic laparoscopy is not the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis and may be reserved for unstable patients. This patient should have an abdominal x-ray performed.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) Abdomen/Pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: CT Abdomen/Pelvis should be utilized sparingly in neonates, infants, and children because of exposure to potentially unnecessary radiation. An abdominal X-ray is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice in neonates with suspected necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).  
✅ Abdominal radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ No testing is necessary, a clinical diagnosis can be made:
Incorrect: For patients with suspected necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) clinical diagnosis should be paired with imaging to make the diagnosis. Suppose patients are located in an area with limited resources. In that case, clinicians should not delay medical management for a presumed diagnosis, but the diagnosis should generally be made initially with a combination of clinical findings and abdominal radiographs.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasonography is increasingly helpful in the diagnosis and management of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The use of ultrasonography is limited by variability of operator expertise, lack of 24-hour availability, and insufficient data to accurately apply findings for management decisions (e.g., surgery). Abdominal x-ray is still considered essential for making the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-week-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of lethargy, feeding intolerance, and bloody stools. The mother states that the patient had two bloody bowel movements in the past 24 hours and has not been able to tolerate breast milk for two days, which he was previously tolerating well. The mother’s pregnancy was complicated by intrauterine growth restriction. Temperature is 38.6 °C (101.5 °C), heart rate is 145/min, and respiratory rate is 35/min. Upon examination, the patient is arousable and moves all four extremities, he has dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation. Abdominal x-ray is obtained and shows dilated loops of the bowel without signs of perforation. Blood work shows leukocytosis and mild thrombocytopenia. Which of the following would be an indication for surgical management in this patient?

choices.text: Pneumatosis intestinalis on initial abdominal x-ray
Clinical deterioration despite optimal medical management
Hypotension that does not respond to intravenous fluids

questions.solution:
In this patient who presents to the emergency department with fever, feeding intolerance, recent bloody bowel movements, and dilated loops of bowel on abdominal x-ray, the most likely diagnosis is necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Medical management is appropriate initial management for patients without signs of peritonitis or perforation who appear to be clinically stable. However, if patients clinically deteriorate despite medical management, then surgery is indicated.
